commit_message:
Handle InstanceUserDataMalformed in create server v2 api

The following patch adds missing support for handling
InstanceUserDataMalformed. In addition, it also adds test cases
in both the v2 and v3 api.

Change-Id: I1b474318248f64eed994f67c6d91db38d5579a63
Closes-bug: #1257146

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-16 21:26:33.000000000', 'message': 'Adds new tag for testonly packages in package lists

Also introduces a new parameter INSTALL_TESTONLY_PACKAGES
in the stackrc with False as default value. Setting it to
True stack.sh will install all packages tagged with the tag
testonly in the package lists.

Includes needed packages for Ubuntu and Fedora

(cherry-picked from commit 71d5630)
Closes-Bug: #1203680
Change-Id: I911a6601819a34262853bba0658f6751148bfbec
'}]
commit_message:
Adds new tag for testonly packages in package lists

Also introduces a new parameter INSTALL_TESTONLY_PACKAGES
in the stackrc with False as default value. Setting it to
True stack.sh will install all packages tagged with the tag
testonly in the package lists.

Includes needed packages for Ubuntu and Fedora

(cherry-picked from commit 71d5630)
Closes-Bug: #1203680
Change-Id: I911a6601819a34262853bba0658f6751148bfbec

'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-12-03 21:46:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-03 21:46:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-noop http://logs.openstack.org/49/59849/2/check/gate-noop/f947c37 : SUCCESS in 2s
'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-12-03 21:46:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 5956, 'date': '2013-12-04 11:43:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Looks good to me, just a couple of comments inline.'}, {'account_id': 994, 'date': '2013-12-04 18:10:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Getting better, need some explanations"}, {'account_id': 994, 'date': '2013-12-04 18:12:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-12-10 20:24:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

questioning the need for an API here -- after talking with marek, my understanding is that apache plugin will handle this piece, while the only thing required for bp auth-saml is processing a set of assertions passed in the WSGI/CGI environment from the apache plugin down to keystone using the correct mapping, and spitting a token back out. that means that some request to the IdP API, for example:

  POST /v3/OS-IDP/identity_providers/CERN/protocols/saml2

... would result in an unscoped token that can be rescoped to a project/domain through the usual means."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-12-10 20:25:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

also, auth-saml isn't a valid bp.. perhaps this was intended for saml-id? https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/saml-id"}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2013-12-11 22:02:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-12-13 02:20:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Marek got something nice working with apache plugins: mod_shib and mod_mellon. There is also a plugin for openid connect. 

So I don't think this api spec is necessary atm, I'll let it expire, if something comes up where we need it, i can restore it. But hopefully the plugins will do the heavy lifting and protocol dancing."}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2013-12-16 16:30:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Steve, this is fine. Yes please do let this expire as Kent has put up a revised version which has corrected the mistakes in this one. We still believe this spec is necessary at the moment for those installations that do not wish to use Apache httpd."}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2013-12-16 16:31:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

EDIT
Our revised Federation PT 3 spec can now be found here https://review.openstack.org/#/c/62417/'}, {'account_id': 994, 'date': '2013-12-16 20:42:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-12-17 01:52:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Please review https://review.openstack.org/#/c/62417 instead.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-03 21:44:29.000000000', 'message': 'Add IdP management extension (Federation pt1)

Add an extension to manage IdPs, this is required for adding
federation support to keystone. Heavily influenced by prior
work done by Kristy and David.

Co-Authored-By: Kristy Siu <kwss@kent.ac.uk>
Co-Authored-By: David Chadwick <d.w.chadwick@kent.ac.uk>
Co-Authored-By: Joe Savak <jsavak@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Marek Denis <marek.denis@cern.ch>

Change-Id: I62cd00aea6c389a875d66d5528b265252e3af735
Implements: blueprint auth-saml
'}, {'created': '2013-12-03 21:46:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for authenticating with saml (Federation pt3)

To complete federation, we should be able to handle authentication
requests that come in saml. Heavily influenced by prior work done
by Kristy and David.

Co-Authored-By: Kristy Siu <kwss@kent.ac.uk>
Co-Authored-By: David Chadwick <d.w.chadwick@kent.ac.uk>
Co-Authored-By: Joe Savak <jsavak@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Marek Denis <marek.denis@cern.ch>
Implements: blueprint auth-saml

Change-Id: I62cd00aea6c389a875d66d5528b265252e3af735
'}]
commit_message:
Add support for authenticating with saml (Federation pt3)

To complete federation, we should be able to handle authentication
requests that come in saml. Heavily influenced by prior work done
by Kristy and David.

Co-Authored-By: Kristy Siu <kwss@kent.ac.uk>
Co-Authored-By: David Chadwick <d.w.chadwick@kent.ac.uk>
Co-Authored-By: Joe Savak <jsavak@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Marek Denis <marek.denis@cern.ch>
Implements: blueprint auth-saml

Change-Id: I62cd00aea6c389a875d66d5528b265252e3af735

commit_message:
Add lockmode in IPAllocation query in delete_subnet in ML2

We faced several issues regarding to IPAllocation table lock.
We have fixed these issues using lockmode. All of IPAllocation query
in db plugin has lockmode. However ML2 delete_subnt isn't using.
This may cause a dead locking issue, so we are adding it
in this commit.

Partially fixes bug: 1243726

Change-Id: I7f11483556feb282a150557dd7c28eacc9a0373d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-20 16:18:38.000000000', 'message': 'Limited use trusts

Trusts now have a "remaining_uses" field that track how many times
a trust can still issue a token. It is decremented each time a
trust related authentication occurs. If set to -1, trusts can be
used indefinitely to authenticate.

Fix for bug #1250617

Change-Id: I739cd583eea2363724b888e9c2b9b9158a9838c1
'}, {'created': '2013-11-22 09:27:09.000000000', 'message': 'Limited use trusts

Trusts now have a "remaining_uses" field that track how many times
a trust can still issue a token. It is decremented each time a
trust related authentication occurs. If set to null, trusts can be
used indefinitely to authenticate.

Fix for bug #1250617

Change-Id: I739cd583eea2363724b888e9c2b9b9158a9838c1
'}, {'created': '2013-11-25 10:22:08.000000000', 'message': 'Limited use trusts

Trusts now have a "remaining_uses" field that track how many times
a trust can still issue a token. It is decremented each time a
trust related authentication occurs. If set to null, trusts can be
used indefinitely to authenticate.

Fix for bug #1250617

Change-Id: I739cd583eea2363724b888e9c2b9b9158a9838c1
'}]
commit_message:
Limited use trusts

Trusts now have a "remaining_uses" field that track how many times
a trust can still issue a token. It is decremented each time a
trust related authentication occurs. If set to null, trusts can be
used indefinitely to authenticate.

Fix for bug #1250617

Change-Id: I739cd583eea2363724b888e9c2b9b9158a9838c1

review comment with just the text:

commit_message:
Enable tasks REST API for async worker

- add REST API layer for async worker(tasks) to
support tasks operations.
- update to include sparse task for tasks.index
- add domain proxies for handling  authorization,
policy enforce, notification while processing
task requests.
- add Task domain entity and TaskFactory to create
new Task domain entity objects.
- add integration test for testing tasks api

Co-authored-by: Fei Long Wang <flwang@cn.ibm.com>

Partially implement blueprint async-glance-workers

Change-Id: I072cbf351c06f59a7702733b652bfa63e5abbaa6

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-12 20:10:52.000000000', 'message': 'Use a global pip.conf for tempest tox calls

* devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh: If tempest is being run, create an
/etc/pip.conf file similar to that used by the root, jenkins and
stack users.

* devstack-vm-gate.sh: For tempest tox commands, pass PIP_CONF_FILE
under sudo to work around its environment filters.

Change-Id: I9be4bdfb9d8d1966e8ddfbeaec75c98e475026e6
'}, {'created': '2013-12-12 20:29:20.000000000', 'message': 'Use a global pip.conf for tempest tox calls

* devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh: If tempest is being run, create an
/etc/pip.conf file similar to that used by the root, jenkins and
stack users.

* devstack-vm-gate.sh: For tempest tox commands, pass
PIP_CONFIG_FILE under sudo to work around its environment filters.
See http://www.pip-installer.org/en/latest/configuration.html for
details.

Closes-Bug: #1260371
Change-Id: I9be4bdfb9d8d1966e8ddfbeaec75c98e475026e6
'}, {'created': '2013-12-12 22:11:57.000000000', 'message': 'Cover the tempest user in select_mirror

* devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh: Add the same mirror configuration for
the tempest account as is set for root, jenkins and stack users.

Closes-Bug: #1260371
Change-Id: I9be4bdfb9d8d1966e8ddfbeaec75c98e475026e6
'}, {'created': '2013-12-12 22:23:16.000000000', 'message': 'Cover the tempest user in select_mirror

* devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh: Add the same mirror configuration for
the tempest account as is set for root, jenkins and stack users.

Closes-Bug: #1260371
Change-Id: I9be4bdfb9d8d1966e8ddfbeaec75c98e475026e6
'}]
commit_message:
Cover the tempest user in select_mirror

* devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh: Add the same mirror configuration for
the tempest account as is set for root, jenkins and stack users.

Closes-Bug: #1260371
Change-Id: I9be4bdfb9d8d1966e8ddfbeaec75c98e475026e6

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-13 14:22:34.000000000', 'message': 'Support oslo-rootwrap in lib/cinder

Make lib/cinder support both cinder-rootwrap (current case) and
oslo-rootwrap (future case) to handle the Cinder transition towards
oslo-rootwrap usage peacefully.

Related blueprint:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/cinder-oslo-rootwrap

Change-Id: I663986304bd74cb6d72d51c553540fb5f9db1d1d
'}]
commit_message:
Support oslo-rootwrap in lib/cinder

Make lib/cinder support both cinder-rootwrap (current case) and
oslo-rootwrap (future case) to handle the Cinder transition towards
oslo-rootwrap usage peacefully.

Related blueprint:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/cinder-oslo-rootwrap

Change-Id: I663986304bd74cb6d72d51c553540fb5f9db1d1d

subject: Move objects tests which are hitting DB into functionaltests
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 668, 'name': 'Adrian Otto', 'email': 'aotto@aotto.com', 'username': 'aotto'}, {'_account_id': 2506, 'name': 'devdatta-kulkarni', 'email': 'kulkarni.devdatta@gmail.com', 'username': 'devdatta-kulkarni'}, {'_account_id': 4190, 'name': 'lifeless', 'email': 'robertc@robertcollins.net', 'username': 'lifeless'}, {'_account_id': 4715, 'name': 'Angus Salkeld', 'email': 'asalkeld@redhat.com', 'username': 'asalkeld'}, {'_account_id': 8334, 'name': 'Noorul Islam K M', 'email': 'noorul@noorul.com', 'username': 'noorul'}, {'_account_id': 9124, 'name': 'Clayton Coleman', 'email': 'ccoleman@redhat.com', 'username': 'clayton.coleman'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8334, 'date': '2013-12-14 16:28:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 668, 'date': '2013-12-14 16:34:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-14 16:44:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-solum-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/72/62172/2/check/gate-solum-pep8/ded8916 : SUCCESS in 1m 02s
- gate-solum-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/72/62172/2/check/gate-solum-python26/7cc1435 : SUCCESS in 1m 04s
- gate-solum-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/72/62172/2/check/gate-solum-python27/e03fb37 : SUCCESS in 1m 09s
- gate-solum-python33 http://logs.openstack.org/72/62172/2/check/gate-solum-python33/cec2446 : SUCCESS in 5m 04s
- gate-solum-pypy http://logs.openstack.org/72/62172/2/check/gate-solum-pypy/e7e23d2 : FAILURE in 1m 36s (non-voting)
- gate-solum-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/72/62172/2/check/gate-solum-docs/f1626ab/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 59s
- gate-solum-devstack-dsvm http://logs.openstack.org/72/62172/2/check/gate-solum-devstack-dsvm/c5cf637 : SUCCESS in 9m 25s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 9124, 'date': '2013-12-15 17:23:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-12-15 23:21:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It was my understanding that the tests that go into functionaltests/ would be tests that eventually go into tempest. If so this is not at the level of tempest tests. I agree they are a bit functional, but tempest tests are a whole "other thing". They use public API to do real things. Like create guests/networks, work the rest API. Not use internal python classes to see if the db works.
IMHO - not the right place, I really see no problem with where they are.'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-16 00:09:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

ack on Angus's point: these are tests that belong in the unit test suite. Don't get hung up on the name of the suite :)"}, {'account_id': 668, 'date': '2013-12-16 03:54:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not merge

Upon inspection of the contents of these tests, I now agree that these are actually already in the right place.'}, {'account_id': 8334, 'date': '2013-12-16 04:07:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In that case will that be a good idea to have a structure like the following?

solum/tests/unit/ - Real unit tests. Tests which can be run without having some service to be running (http, db, etc).
solum/tests/functional - Tests that needs some service to be running.'}, {'account_id': 668, 'date': '2013-12-16 04:14:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Our database code allows for the use of SQLite, so an additional running service is not required.'}, {'account_id': 8334, 'date': '2013-12-16 04:21:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

But still that is an I/O'}, {'account_id': 2506, 'date': '2013-12-16 19:38:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

+1 to Adrian's point."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-16 21:43:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Noorul, your point is valid in a theoretical sense, but as long as we have our tests run fast, not in a practical sense. I say this having had a fast 10000+ test test suite for bzr, which was heavily dependent on I/O. 

Secondly, Sqlite in-memory DB's don't hit disk. We should be able to test with that easily."}, {'account_id': 8334, 'date': '2013-12-17 01:20:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-17 00:59:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix cinder migration script logic error

Script condition was logically opposite, as we only need to run losetup
-f if we could not find an existing loopback for the file.

Change-Id: Ib57c07ac26fa4c0bba66dda9ca5a95cb208a2b96
'}]
commit_message:
Fix cinder migration script logic error

Script condition was logically opposite, as we only need to run losetup
-f if we could not find an existing loopback for the file.

Change-Id: Ib57c07ac26fa4c0bba66dda9ca5a95cb208a2b96

commit_message:
Make rejoin-stack.sh resume file logging if enabled

This patch ensures that screen will resume logging to files
after rejoin-stack.sh when SCREEN_LOGDIR is set.

Change-Id: I4c3eae0df7755b700dd8acf4bf14b7e383372ca3
Closes-bug: 1192568

commit_message:
Setup destination disk from virt_disk_size

When running live-migration --block-migrate on a qcow2 backed
VM without cow image, the destination qcow2 file should be created
with the virtual disk size. For raw images, the virt_disk_size
is set to disk_size to ensure that virt_disk_size is always the
size of the disk that should be re-created.

Update unit tests to be more strict and check for sizes to be correct.

Closes-Bug: #1257355

Change-Id: Ie3be46024f06b9f59af92f5e3918a1958386d4f1

commit_message:
Add tests for keystone OS-TRUST v3 API

Add tests providing coverage of the keystone v3 OS-TRUSTS extension,
as documented at:
https://github.com/openstack/identity-api/blob/master/\
openstack-identity-api/v3/src/markdown/identity-api-v3-os-trust-ext.md

This covers all the documented interfaces to create/delete/list/get
trusts and roles delegated by trusts, except those impacted by bug
1246383 and 1245590, which will be submitted separately.

A subsequent patch will add coverage for consuming trusts via the tokens API.

Note only the JSON API is currently tested due to bug #1246941

Partially-Implements: blueprint keystone-trust-api
Change-Id: I310951f070107f3af33b52fcd2c8e54d82654088

commit_message:
Modify to set actual 'connection' in neutron.conf

No one sets the 'connection' params at the '[database]' section in
neutron.conf.

Closes-Bug: #1261298

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-10 04:29:06.000000000', 'message': "Enable is_newer_than and is_older_than to compare offset aware datetimes

Avoid 'TypeError: can't subtract offset-naive and offset-aware datetimes'
when an offset aware datetime is passed in.

Change-Id: Ib01568c9d287e319750b6bef3656fdcfc992a1b1
Closes-Bug: #1259383
"}, {'created': '2013-12-10 04:34:44.000000000', 'message': "Avoid TypeError in is_older_than, is_newer_than

datetime doesn't like to subtract offset-naive and
offset-aware datetimes. To fix this we convert all
datetimes that are passed in to offset-naive objects.

Change-Id: Ib01568c9d287e319750b6bef3656fdcfc992a1b1
Closes-Bug: #1259383
"}, {'created': '2013-12-10 17:20:30.000000000', 'message': "Avoid TypeError in is_older_than, is_newer_than

datetime doesn't like to subtract offset-naive and
offset-aware datetimes. To fix this we convert all
datetimes that are passed in to offset-naive objects.

Change-Id: Ib01568c9d287e319750b6bef3656fdcfc992a1b1
Closes-Bug: #1259383
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid TypeError in is_older_than, is_newer_than

datetime doesn't like to subtract offset-naive and
offset-aware datetimes. To fix this we convert all
datetimes that are passed in to offset-naive objects.

Change-Id: Ib01568c9d287e319750b6bef3656fdcfc992a1b1
Closes-Bug: #1259383

commit_message:
Change keystone_default_role to _member_

Previously both Member & _member_ roles were created, which lead to
confision.
Member role is not created anymore as of [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#q,If4ed1c2c72ca67acad7b70651e68ff7ce68157dd,n,z

Change-Id: I933236c2c257b65a1027da07a760c8b4d10618cc

commit_message:
Make parameter doc RDoc compatible

This patch fixes the parameter documentation in
generic_service, network, objectstore, params,
qpid and quota to conform with the style guide and
support autogenerating parameter documentation.

Change-Id: I43faab3c59a25bf233e985d75f906a4ba026f440

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-06 18:25:19.000000000', 'message': "Update tempest hacking regarding unit tests.

This commit just updates some of the hacking documentation around unit
tests. It also adds a new hacking rule to ensure that setUpClass isn't

commit_message:
Update tempest hacking regarding unit tests

This commit just updates some of the hacking documentation around unit
tests. It also adds a new hacking rule to ensure that setUpClass isn't
used for the unit tests.

Partially implements bp unit-tests

Change-Id: Ie8b1c9f1312a467265d53bc28ee905fa1b5fbb53

I didn't get as much on this as i'd like and i remember i had some more.

I'm not quite sure of the expected usage, but are we ok to uniquely identify hosts like that? Should groups and keys be assigned a UUID and have name and key as attributes? Why should we assume only one key per host, what about transitions? 

Why are we passing around so much json as a b64 encoded string? I understand that the signature is probably generated from this, but can't we pass the json and expect people to do there own signature generation?"}, {'account_id': 7060, 'date': '2013-08-13 12:19:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

Jamie:
> I'm not quite sure of the expected usage, but are we ok to uniquely identify hosts like that?

That's how "services" (not hosts) are identified by the message queues, there is no other way.

> Should groups and keys be assigned a UUID and have name and key as attributes?

Internally the database uses a HASH to index stuff, but it makes little sense to expose it.

> Why should we assume only one key per host, what about transitions?

It's not per host, it is per service per host.
Transitions of what kind ?

> Why are we passing around so much json as a b64 encoded string? I understand that the signature is probably generated from this, but can't we pass the json and expect people to do there own signature generation?

Because arrays are unordered in python, and signatures will fail if a single byte is different, let alone having elements of the json buffer moved around. And you do not want to depend on json.dumps from different implementations or versions to produce a bit-by-bit identical output from the same iput, there is no guaranteee of that.

By using base64 we are sure that the elements that must not be changed are not and they will properly verify the signature.'}, {'account_id': 7060, 'date': '2013-08-13 15:34:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2013-08-13 19:23:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (17 inline comments)

From a security perspective I think this API looks reasonable, but I don't know if it's following the generally accepted format"}, {'account_id': 9098, 'date': '2013-12-03 23:48:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I have a new copy of the API document that addresses the previous review comments, plus adds clarification in some areas.  There are a few areas that seem problematic to me though:

- The description of the ticket says that it contains an encrypted SEK pair in "esek", which are the keys for the receiver.  Just below that, the description of the contents of "esek" show that it only includes one key, a timestamp, and a TTL.  Shouldn't it contain "skey" and "ekey"?  The definition of "skey" is "Message Signing Key", which implies that it is used to sign messages.  The receiving party will be unable to do a HMAC check if it doesn't have the key that was used by the sender.

- The "Set Key" API says that there is a default of a 128 bit random key, which implies key generation on the KDS side.  How is it returned in the response?  The response isn't currently described, though we show an example with "name" and "generation" key value pairs.

- How does a group recipient know that it needs to look for a group key?  We don't currently describe what a source sends to a destination when it establishes communication, though it's obvious that it sends "esek" from the ticket.  The problem is that "esek" doesn't contain any information about the destination name that the source used.  How is the destination to know if the keys it receives from the source are encrypted with it's own long-term key or a short-lived group key that it needs to fetch from KDS?

If I can get clarification on the above, I can add the details to my working copy of the markdown and update the patchset here.'}, {'account_id': 7060, 'date': '2013-12-04 02:04:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

> The description of the ticket says that it contains an encrypted SEK pair in "esek", which are the keys for the receiver. Just below that, the description of the contents of "esek" show that it only includes one key, a timestamp, and a TTL. Shouldn't it contain "skey" and "ekey"? The definition of "skey" is "Message Signing Key", which implies that it is used to sign messages. The receiving party will be unable to do a HMAC check if it doesn't have the key that was used by the sender.

It's a key pair, it gets split in a signing and an encryption key by the receiving party.

>    The "Set Key" API says that there is a default of a 128 bit random key, which implies key generation on the KDS side. How is it returned in the response? The response isn't currently described, though we show an example with "name" and "generation" key value pairs.

The key generation is used only for group keys.
Keys for one-to-one tickets are derivde using HKDF from the long term keys of the services.

>    How does a group recipient know that it needs to look for a group key?

It know because the metadata contains a destination name that is a group and includes a generation number.

> We don't currently describe what a source sends to a destination when it establishes communication, though it's obvious that it sends "esek" from the ticket. The problem is that "esek" doesn't contain any information about the destination name that the source used.

That information is known to the destination as it subscribes to a topic by a specific name, and the RPC packet includes a signature that includes metadata which specifies a source and a target. This is not specified in the KDS because it is applicatio to application communication protocol and not an API.

The message format used for message queues is described in the document linked at the top:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/MessageSecurity#Message_Integrity_and_Confidentiality

> How is the destination to know if the keys it receives from the source are encrypted with it's own long-term key or a short-lived group key that it needs to fetch from KDS?

Please read the above document.'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-12-04 03:53:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

> > The description of the ticket says that it contains an encrypted SEK pair in "esek", which are the keys for the receiver. Just below that, the description of the contents of "esek" show that it only includes one key, a timestamp, and a TTL. Shouldn't it contain "skey" and "ekey"? The definition of "skey" is "Message Signing Key", which implies that it is used to sign messages. The receiving party will be unable to do a HMAC check if it doesn't have the key that was used by the sender.

> It's a key pair, it gets split in a signing and an encryption key by the receiving party.

Checked with simo on irc - this is wrong. The key here is the seed from which the skey and ekey can be derived from.'}, {'account_id': 9098, 'date': '2013-12-04 19:47:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-04 19:48:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Works for me

commit_message:
Key Distribution Server

API for distribution of keys in support of:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/MessageSecurity#Key_Derivation

SecurityImpact
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ic00009e635f81427ba909a9ce4ba168f14ff51df

* list_volumes and list_volumes_with_detail for nova volume extension

* list_snapshots and list_snapshots_with_detail for Cinder API

with the corresponding xml client method "list_snapshots_with_detail"

Fixes bug #1086590

commit_message:
Add testcases for volume

Adds tests for those GET API functions that accept params

List_volumes and list_volumes_with_detail for nova volume extension
List_volumes and list_volumes_with_detail for Cinder API
List_snapshots and list_snapshots_with_detail for Cinder API
Fixed typo in volume snapshot json client to make it consistent
with the corresponding xml client method "list_snapshots_with_detail"

Partial-Bug: #1086590

Change-Id: Ie703fa8729d838203c12293a7ce1ce942ec83a81

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-11-10 16:51:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi,
I do not think that this is the correct way to go. At the moment this will be a degradation for the user experience. This means that if the user is using horizon and i H They would get a valid error now they will receive an exception.
Why not catch the exception at the driver level and then display a valid message.
In addition to this the change in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/55752/2/nova/virt/hyperv/driver.py contradicts what you have done here.
This type of a change should be discussed a little more.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-11-10 22:03:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Gary - as I mentioned in the hyperv version of the patch I think its better handled at the API rather than the driver level. Returning a 501 means a program that uses the API can much more easily tell when the console output is not going to be available rather than parsing the string output to see if it failed with driver specific error messages.

Russell - -1 is just to ask if we need to keep the function at all? Also like the hyperv change should depend on an API change to catch the NotImplemented exception"}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2013-11-11 02:24:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Please see the same review on the Hyper-V driver patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/55752/"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-11-11 08:18:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Gary / Chris - agreed with Chris' comments here.  Also, the function can be removed.  The base driver class will raise the same thing.  I think I was just leaving it in for the comment that's in the code.  But honestly, if the underlying code it's referring to isn't used, it should be removed, too."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-11-11 08:54:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-11-11 09:31:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-10 14:52:53.000000000', 'message': "vmwareapi: raise on get_console_output

Commit 2ce3461595a490c9a02272ee4a1ab1eb55c27f60 updated
get_console_output() in the vmwareapi driver to return a static string.
Since this isn't supported, I think the most correct thing to do here is
to raise NotImplementedError.  That will get properly propogated back
through the API.

The original change was concerned with getting a friendly message to the
user.  That should be done by the consumer of the API.  For example, if
Horizon got that as an error back, it could present a special message to
the user indicating that the operation is not supported for that
instance.

Change-Id: Ia17330b9084bf3e82219a0c143485174c3e8f6db

commit_message:
vmwareapi: raise on get_console_output

Commit 2ce3461595a490c9a02272ee4a1ab1eb55c27f60 updated
get_console_output() in the vmwareapi driver to return a static string.
Since this isn't supported, I think the most correct thing to do here is
to raise NotImplementedError.  That will get properly propogated back
through the API.

The original change was concerned with getting a friendly message to the
user.  That should be done by the consumer of the API.  For example, if
Horizon got that as an error back, it could present a special message to
the user indicating that the operation is not supported for that
instance.

Change-Id: Ia17330b9084bf3e82219a0c143485174c3e8f6db

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-11-10 16:52:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Please see the comments at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/55753/ - this is something that needs to be discussed on this list - worst case if that the driver should catch the exception so that the user does not experience and exception."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-11-10 21:57:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

garyk - isn't this the sort of situation that 501 Not Implemented is for? 

Russell - it looks like neither the v2 or v3 console output plugins actually catch NotImplemented. We should explicitly catch it and raise the webob exception as otherwise we'll log a stack trace. For V3, 501 should be added to the expected exceptions decorator."}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2013-11-11 02:22:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

IMO although a NotImplementedError is semantically correct in the driver, with the current status of the API it would propagate to the UI. 

To solve this, I agree with adding a patch on the V2 and V3 API to catch the exception and return the proper HTTP code plus a coordinated patch in Horizon to provide a meaningful message to the user."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-11-11 08:15:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

gary - The driver should not catch anything.  We want the exception to raise back to the API layer.  It does need to be added as a client exception so that the rpc layer treats it as expected, though.

Chris - Thanks.  I thought this exception was handled and translated generically in the API.  I didn't think about needing to catch it specifically to avoid a stack trace in the API.

Alessandro - We need to separate what's right for the compute API vs what happens in Horizon.  A bug in Horizon for a friendly message makes sense, but I don't think this patch should block on it.  I think getting an error makes a whole lot more sense than silently returning an empty log."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-11-11 08:54:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-11-11 08:55:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I could argue the same thing for the vmware drivers:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/vmwareapi/driver.py#L268

That's only in the esx driver and the vc driver doesn't override get_console_output, but it's vmops class does implement a get_console_output method.

================

Also, seems we should have a unit test in the hyperv driver tests that asserts that NotImplementedError is raised when called."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-12-13 15:46:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Well nevermind about the vmware driver(s), that's in change Ia17330b9084bf3e82219a0c143485174c3e8f6db - always one step ahead of me. :)

How about a unit test in the hyperv virt driver tests to assert the NotImplementedError though?  That would be an indication of regression if someone changes it back to an empty string again later."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-13 16:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

The get_console_method() in the hyperv driver only logged a debug
message and returned an empty string.  It seems like much better and
expected behavior to not implement the method at all so that a
NotImplementedError is raised.  This will properly propagate back
through the API.  Not Implemented is certainly different to the user
than telling them their console output is always empty.

commit_message:
hyperv: remove get_console_output method

The get_console_method() in the hyperv driver only logged a debug
message and returned an empty string.  It seems like much better and
expected behavior to not implement the method at all so that a
NotImplementedError is raised.  This will properly propagate back
through the API.  Not Implemented is certainly different to the user
than telling them their console output is always empty.

Change-Id: I9df81a74ac533a73f30305f3eb12a8ff7608b293

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-11 08:54:20.000000000', 'message': 'List NotImplementedError as client exception

Mark NotImplementedError as a client exception for the
get_console_output rpc api method.  This is an expected result if the
driver does not implement this functionality.  If raised, the rpc layer
should not log a traceback.

Change-Id: I60747bf48c378053eb0d36337fcc26201b4840f9
'}, {'created': '2013-11-11 10:27:41.000000000', 'message': 'List NotImplementedError as client exception

Mark NotImplementedError as a client exception for the
get_console_output rpc api method.  This is an expected result if the
driver does not implement this functionality.  If raised, the rpc layer

commit_message:
List NotImplementedError as client exception

Mark NotImplementedError as a client exception for the
get_console_output rpc api method.  This is an expected result if the
driver does not implement this functionality.  If raised, the rpc layer
should not log a traceback.

Change-Id: I60747bf48c378053eb0d36337fcc26201b4840f9

subject: api: handle NotImplementedError for console output

commit_message:
api: handle NotImplementedError for console output

Some drivers do not implement getting console output.  Catch this
exception at the API layer and return a 501 from the API in this case.

Change-Id: I144850f4431a7588430da298ba348039bed25403

I still do not like these tests that modify the system environment. Isn't there a race if the json and xml run at the same time around the update_description test? 
This sequence is bad:

JSON: update description
XML: update description
JSON: check description (ok because the value is the same for both)
JSON: cleanup, sets back to original description
XML: check description (will see original, not what it set in step 2)"}, {'account_id': 8172, 'date': '2013-12-04 02:48:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

I found some docs about this issue, maybe it can help. http://docs.openstack.org/developer/tempest/HACKING.html#parallel-test-execution .

commit_message:
actually turn on neutron cli tests

the cli tests for neutron were never running in the gate,
because neutron doesn't run a full run, so these had to
be marked as smoke tests. This is getting old....

Change-Id: I1bb61e357a5f1dc30345771bf12732d3461311f9

subject: Move testtools to requirements.txt
messages:
[{'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-16 21:11:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'd prefer to install testtools - specifically, install the test-requirements for solum - since we use testtools everywhere else, including in tempest, not having it will lead to having to think harder about how we write these tests."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-12-16 21:17:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

OK.  Well, the tests fail in the devstack-gate VM right now because testtools isn't installed.  I guess the fix is to move it to requirements.txt from test-requirements.txt so devstack installs it ..."}, {'account_id': 668, 'date': '2013-12-16 21:17:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Move testtools to requirements.txt

The devstack-gate job is failing on the functional tests because
testtools is not installed.  Move testtools to requirements.txt so
devstack installs it when installing solum.

Change-Id: I055a285a901cbbec3745b27dc6b3d7334ea3cd13

[{'account_id': 6896, 'date': '2013-12-06 15:35:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

did you mean to add a teardown() or replace setup() with a teardown()'}, {'account_id': 6969, 'date': '2013-12-06 15:42:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

No I have just moved the libvirt._reset() from the setUp method into the tearDown so that it gets called after the tests run.

This sets the allow_default_uri_connection back to True so that if any other test runs and requires this set to True then it is.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-06 16:20:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2013-12-09 21:44:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

As mentioned in 1258603, I think the correct fix is to reset libvirt.allow_default_uri_connection=True in FakeLibvirtTests.test_openAuth_can_refuse_None_uri test."}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-12-12 15:21:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

I really fail to see how this could possibly fix the race. Both setUp and tearDown happen around every test.

Do correct me if I am wrong.'}, {'account_id': 6896, 'date': '2013-12-12 15:25:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Just a thought, does a global variable gets shared between many threads of a tox run?'}, {'account_id': 6969, 'date': '2013-12-12 16:48:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Nikola, the difference between setup and teardown is that when the test changes the value of the global variable the teardown resets it back to the default value straight away. This leaves a very small window when the other tests run that depend on the global variable been set the way it is.  When we are writing tests we should always clean up after ourselves and leave the environment the way we found it. It is not the same as cleaning up, change the environment and then walking away. This leaves us in the case when potentially everyone has to know what to cleanup and how.

If we leave the resetting in the setup then potentially the window when the value is different can be large or the value is never set back to the original value causing the test_tpool_execute_calls_libvirt test to fail. This is currently happening every time we run the tests at HP. There is sometime in our environment that exercises this.

This issue needs to fixed. The other solutions to this or

a) to put a try: ... finally: libvirt._reset() inside the test around the body that modifies the global variable. But to me this is the same as moving the reset from setup to tearDown.
b) revive https://review.openstack.org/#/c/60005/ but an other reviewer didn't like that patch.
c) we could make sure that the reset method is called by all the libvirt tests during setup.

All these issues suffer from the fact that the issue is still there and people are likely to forget this in the future and remove or forget to add in the _reset and suddenly we are back here. Even with this patch, the if someone changes the value of a global variable they need to cleanup after the test (not before).

This issue is subtle as I never even knew about this global variable (or about the fake libvirt) when working the original threading issue I was trying to resolve."}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2013-12-12 22:39:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This is the exact solution we came up with as well, thanks Michael!'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-12-16 15:59:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

>Nikola, the difference between setup and teardown is that when the test changes the value of the global variable the teardown resets it back to the default value straight away. This leaves a very small window when the other tests run that depend on the global variable been set the way it is. When we are writing tests we should always clean up after ourselves and leave the environment the way we found it. It is not the same as cleaning up, change the environment and then walking away. This leaves us in the case when potentially everyone has to know what to cleanup and how.

The only thing I agree with here is that it makes more sense to clean-up after tests. Slightly more sense. You still have the race - it just happens less (probably there is some non-random ordering of tests that you keep getting).

IMHO - we should do the _reset call also in LibvirtNonblockingTestCase (tearDown if you will move it into tearDown here as well, but up to you). since everyone who messes with allow_default_uri_connection should put it back.

Moving back to -1 since there is an acceptable way for this to progress - but it still needs work.

Also - it wouldn't be bad to add more info into the commit message (which global variable, why etc.)."}, {'account_id': 6969, 'date': '2013-12-16 16:37:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> The only thing I agree with here is that it makes more sense to clean-up after tests. Slightly more sense. You still have the race - it just happens less (probably there is some non-random ordering of tests that you keep getting).

Yes you still have the race but the window in which to hit it is much reduced. When using global variables like this you are always going to be running into a chance of one test stepping on the toes of an other test. To remove the race completely I would have to remove the global variable. I don't think we have to go down this route as it is a lot of work for what you get.

> IMHO - we should do the _reset call also in LibvirtNonblockingTestCase (tearDown if you will move it into tearDown here as well, but up to you). since everyone who messes with allow_default_uri_connection should put it back.

I disagree. LibvirtNonblockingTestCase doesn't actually mess with allow_default_uri_connection, so it doesn't have to clean up after itself nor should it need to setup anything. LibvirtNonblockTestCase actually doesn't use the fake driver all the time so calling _reset here will not make a slight bit of difference when using the real driver. My test setup uses the real libvirt driver by default, ci.openstack.org uses the real one, but many people run the unit tests inside a virtualenv which uses the fake libvirt driver.

The test that does mess with allow_default_uri_connection needs to cleanup after itself and this is what this patch fixes making the environment more consistent but not perfect as we mentioned above.

> Also - it wouldn't be bad to add more info into the commit message (which global variable, why etc.).

Fair point."}, {'account_id': 6969, 'date': '2013-12-16 16:46:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-12-16 16:46:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2013-12-16 17:03:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

You disregarded all my comments but the one about the commit message, so -1 stays"}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-12-16 17:19:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Ah sorry I missed the reply - let me read it.'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-12-16 17:27:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

OK - I didn't look deeply enough as to what test_tpool_execute_calls_libvirt does - and it indeed does not mess with the global so no need to do anything there.

I think the intention would be more clear if we actually did it in a finally: like you suggested in a previous comment - but that's academic really."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-16 17:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

[{'created': '2013-12-06 15:29:42.000000000', 'message': 'Fix race in unit tests, which can cause gate job to fail

If the FakeLibvirtTests.test_openAuth_can_refuse_None_uri test
runs before the LibvirtNonblockingTestCase.test_tpool_execute_calls_libvirt
test then the later fails as the former changes a global variable.

This change cleanups the test after running, and not before.

Change-Id: I68c30dffd05daae6c0d5fbc6ec005c0fab4f09be
Closes-Bug: 1258553
'}, {'created': '2013-12-16 16:46:19.000000000', 'message': "Fix race in unit tests, which can cause gate job to fail

The FakeLibvirtTests.test_openAuth_can_refuse_None_uri test changes the value
of the global variable allow_default_uri_connection. We need to clean up this
change up after running this test so as we don't effect other tests that
expect the value of this variable to be the default.

In particular this test was running before the
LibvirtNonblockingTestCase.test_tpool_execute_calls_libvirt which ran when
the value was changed causing this test to fail. This only occurred when we
the test_libvirt used the fake libvirt driver, which happens when the tests
run inside a virtualenv environment.

Change-Id: I68c30dffd05daae6c0d5fbc6ec005c0fab4f09be
Closes-Bug: 1258553
"}]
commit_message:
Fix race in unit tests, which can cause gate job to fail

The FakeLibvirtTests.test_openAuth_can_refuse_None_uri test changes the value
of the global variable allow_default_uri_connection. We need to clean up this
change up after running this test so as we don't effect other tests that
expect the value of this variable to be the default.

In particular this test was running before the
LibvirtNonblockingTestCase.test_tpool_execute_calls_libvirt which ran when
the value was changed causing this test to fail. This only occurred when we
the test_libvirt used the fake libvirt driver, which happens when the tests
run inside a virtualenv environment.

Change-Id: I68c30dffd05daae6c0d5fbc6ec005c0fab4f09be
Closes-Bug: 1258553

commit_message:
Add test-requirements to all tox jobs

With the addition of unit tests to tempest that have requirements
in the test-requirements.txt the regular tempest jobs will fail
during test discovery. This is because the packages in
test-requirements aren't being installed which will cause an import
error when subunit imports the unit test file. This commit gets
around the issue by installing the packages in test-requirements for
every tox job.

Change-Id: I00e66fae2dfe123dd3b5769265a9d64f913c00a5

commit_message:
Fix --debug handling in the shell

This sets the debug level globally on root logger so that every debug
calls are logged.

Change-Id: Ia8d61f213b2bc6c4bcb1038e7ff6ac0104581b4b
Closes-Bug: #1259210

Make cinder buildable stand-alone

Cinder needs some python modules that make use of libssl-dev for
installation.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-16 19:49:26.000000000', 'message': 'Make cinder loopback config idempotent

If this script is run twice for some reason, it will attach more and
more loopback devices to the backing file which is problematic. Using -j
will use the first device if one has already been attached.

Change-Id: Idcc84b308e1edcdb9ab819f2f4a5fc465ef5661e
'}]
commit_message:
Make cinder loopback config idempotent

If this script is run twice for some reason, it will attach more and
more loopback devices to the backing file which is problematic. Using -j
will use the first device if one has already been attached.

Change-Id: Idcc84b308e1edcdb9ab819f2f4a5fc465ef5661e

Closes-Bug: #1261422

commit_message:
Filter out LVM block devices for cinder

Cinder may create physical LVM volumes which might be picked up by the
operating system and treated the wrong way. We can be explicit in the
filter and only allow our loopback device to be seen by pvscan.

Change-Id: I73a5b8ed0c3989ff61a3005cb70acd8a95532271
Closes-Bug: #1261422

commit_message:
Add new env variable to specify test path

This commit adds the env variable OS_TEST_PATH to specify the test
discovery path for testr. This can be used to specify which path will
be used for test discovery.
Closes-Bug: #1260710

Change-Id: Idcc8f6b5d82a2adc1a1f8ad04a47e8d694dc7de7

English clean-up pass fixing minor grammar errors

A copy-edit pass against document "Tempest Coding Guide",
eliminating spurious "the"s, inserting "is" and "to", fixing
some trailing idents due to spurious leading spaces, making
tense match, eliminating run-ons, etc..

commit_message:
removed wrap_exception method from ironic/common/exception.py

method wrap_exception was never used

Closes-Bug: #1250533

Change-Id: I02227a65e5f37a8bd93e6d53f31f28f5633ab8c5

commit_message:
Method to generate PXE options for Neutron ports

Add a new method to generate the structure containing the PXE
bootfile-name, server-ip-address, and tftp-server information.
This information will be used to provide Neutron DHCP options
to set up the PXE booting of nodes. This patch does not actually pass
the data to Neutron, however.

Change-Id: Iadf5b803bb5a5465fc2adcb94fa3fd2a756340be

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-11 14:51:06.000000000', 'message': "Add X-Tenant-ID to metadata request

Previously, one could update a port's device_id to be that of
another tenant's instance_id and then be able to retrieve that
instance's metadata. In order to prevent this X-Tenant-ID is now
passed in the metadata request to nova and nova then checks that
X-Tenant-ID also matches the tenant_id for the instance against it's
database to ensure it's not being spoofed.

DocImpact - When upgrading OpenStack nova and neturon, neutron
            should be updated first (and neutron-metadata-agent
            restarted before nova is upgraded) in order to minimize
            downtime. This is because there is also a patch to nova
            which has checks X-Tenant-ID against it's database
            therefore neutron-metadata-agent needs to pass that
            before nova is upgraded for metadata to work.

Change-Id: I2b8fa2f561a7f2914608e68133abf15efa95015a
Closes-Bug: #1235450
"}]
commit_message:
Add X-Tenant-ID to metadata request

Previously, one could update a port's device_id to be that of
another tenant's instance_id and then be able to retrieve that
instance's metadata. In order to prevent this X-Tenant-ID is now
passed in the metadata request to nova and nova then checks that
X-Tenant-ID also matches the tenant_id for the instance against it's
database to ensure it's not being spoofed.

DocImpact - When upgrading OpenStack nova and neturon, neutron
            should be updated first (and neutron-metadata-agent
            restarted before nova is upgraded) in order to minimize
            downtime. This is because there is also a patch to nova
            which has checks X-Tenant-ID against it's database
            therefore neutron-metadata-agent needs to pass that
            before nova is upgraded for metadata to work.

Change-Id: I2b8fa2f561a7f2914608e68133abf15efa95015a
Closes-Bug: #1235450

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-16 15:33:55.000000000', 'message': "Move decision_maker() call into setUpClass

Previously the class level call of decision_maker() to detect certain
configuration details for the boto tests was mad in the class
definition. This has issues with unit testing because it requires a
functional config at import time for the file. This commit avoids this
restriction by moving this call into setUpClass for BotoTestCase which
won't try to execute decision_maker() at import.

This commit also pins sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error.

Change-Id: I8abf4ae109576499fed6b31ae644c1bac58e3350
(cherry picked from commit f054a9c5f103a0e30e66f69c8f7872097feb3af3)
"}]
commit_message:
Move decision_maker() call into setUpClass

Previously the class level call of decision_maker() to detect certain
configuration details for the boto tests was mad in the class
definition. This has issues with unit testing because it requires a
functional config at import time for the file. This commit avoids this
restriction by moving this call into setUpClass for BotoTestCase which
won't try to execute decision_maker() at import.

This commit also pins sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error.

Change-Id: I8abf4ae109576499fed6b31ae644c1bac58e3350
(cherry picked from commit f054a9c5f103a0e30e66f69c8f7872097feb3af3)

commit_message:
Use setup.py develop for tox install

tox 1.6 was released, so, we can use new develop mode that'll speed up
project installation. Additionally it ensures that installation performs
without --pre to avoid alpha/beta versions.

Change-Id: Ibf21c646cdc389f0b43e0c2a2aae7ded69ad5638

commit_message:
Remove files that are part of openstack-doc-tools

cleanup/* and sitemap/* are part of openstack-doc-tools now, remove
them here.

Note: We cannot remove the whole tools directory yet until all gate jobs
are changed.

Change-Id: I2b810eeb3b9b623ebcafc33defd39251b8dc5ade

commit_message:
Revert graceful shutdown patch

aka: "Stop, Rescue, and Delete should give guest a chance to shutdown"

This reverts commit b32d01d44ca5711c96d192df51bf7acd34f52556.

Unfortunately this patch had an unintended side effect that we didn't
notice until after it was merged.  It adds about 25 minutes to tempest
runs, which isn't really acceptable in the gate.  We need to revert this
until we can sort that out.

Change-Id: Ibdd5c86e60b5ede4ec1a38d9efa7c94d60de1720

commit_message:
Replace Celery with Oslo messaging for asynchronous queuing.

Barbican is using Celery to interface to the HA queues it uses to send
asynchronous requests from API nodes to the worker nodes. This change
request replaces Celery with OpenStack-friendly oslo.messaging RPC
components.

Change-Id: Ibc257e98726938a577da4300b389fa13ff34d8a0
Implements: blueprint queue-use-oslo-messaging

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-04 16:34:19.000000000', 'message': "Don't stop migrations tests on time out

The time it takes to run migrations tests on MySQL and PostgreSQL
on CI nodes varies greatly depending on the current load of nodes.
All our tests are stopped after 160s now. Migrations tests could
be an exception of this rule (as they are the longest ones and we
can't predict how long it will take to run them precisely enough).

Closes-Bug: #1216851

Change-Id: I48d7c125397cd282d52eb8e1a1ccb699188d8f14
"}, {'created': '2013-12-06 08:39:21.000000000', 'message': "Don't stop migrations tests on time out

The time it takes to run migrations tests on MySQL and PostgreSQL
on CI nodes varies greatly depending on the current load of nodes.
All our tests are stopped after 160s now. Migrations tests could
be an exception of this rule (as they are the longest ones and we
can't predict how long it will take to run them precisely enough).

Closes-Bug: #1216851

Change-Id: I48d7c125397cd282d52eb8e1a1ccb699188d8f14
"}, {'created': '2013-12-09 13:34:25.000000000', 'message': "Give migrations tests more time to run

Migrations tests usually take longer to run that most other
tests. Increase the time out value just for migrations tests,
so that we don't hit various time out errors running unit tests
when CI test nodes slow down a bit.

Closes-Bug: #1216851

Change-Id: I48d7c125397cd282d52eb8e1a1ccb699188d8f14
"}]
commit_message:
Give migrations tests more time to run

Migrations tests usually take longer to run that most other
tests. Increase the time out value just for migrations tests,
so that we don't hit various time out errors running unit tests
when CI test nodes slow down a bit.

Closes-Bug: #1216851

Change-Id: I48d7c125397cd282d52eb8e1a1ccb699188d8f14

Currently, we are setting the test timeout value globally

commit_message:
Make it possible to override test timeout value

Currently, we are setting the test timeout value globally
in .testr.conf. It could be useful to be able to override
it per test case (e.g. for migrations tests which usually
take much longer to run than any other tests).

Related-Bug: #1216851

Change-Id: Icee09609f76f4439f6d981641be521d8d695a77e

commit_message:
Adjust import order according to PEP8 imports rule

This patch just adjust import order to follow PEP8 imports rule.
See http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#imports

Imports should be grouped in the following order:
1) Standard library imports
2) Related third party imports
3) Local application/library specific imports

Change-Id: Ifa3f219207b02d60e757e17c42dae1fef2f628fe

subject: Make Serializer/Conductor able to backlevel objects

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-02 21:57:20.000000000', 'message': "WIP Make Serializer/Conductor able to backlevel objects

This is a prototype of an alternate way of handling the situation
where nova-api sends newer objects to an older compute node. In this
case, the serializer detects the IncompatibleObjectVersion error
and asks conductor to backlevel it. This means we call into a new
method in conductor with the primitive object that we can't handle,
and basically ask it to hydrate it and call obj_make_compatible()
on our behalf and pass it back to us.

This eliminates the need for API to know whether it's talking to
an older compute, although it could become problematic later if we
end up with API trying to do something against a compute that really
can't handle it. I imagine some combination of both approaches may
be required.

Change-Id: I4b17c8382619e4f73b83c026bf68549ac67a68a2
"}, {'created': '2013-12-05 19:08:58.000000000', 'message': "Make Serializer/Conductor able to backlevel objects

This is a prototype of an alternate way of handling the situation
where nova-api sends newer objects to an older compute node. In this
case, the serializer detects the IncompatibleObjectVersion error
and asks conductor to backlevel it. This means we call into a new
method in conductor with the primitive object that we can't handle,
and basically ask it to hydrate it and call obj_make_compatible()
on our behalf and pass it back to us.

This eliminates the need for API to know whether it's talking to
an older compute and allows a newer conductor to assist older
compute nodes during upgrades to a significant degree.

Related-Bug: #1258256
Change-Id: I4b17c8382619e4f73b83c026bf68549ac67a68a2

commit_message:
Make Serializer/Conductor able to backlevel objects

This improves handling the situation where nova-api sends newer
objects to an older compute node. In this case, the serializer detects
the IncompatibleObjectVersion error and asks conductor to backlevel it.
This means we call into a new method in conductor with the primitive
object that we can't handle, and basically ask it to hydrate it and
call obj_make_compatible() on our behalf and pass it back to us.

This eliminates the need for API to know whether it's talking to
an older compute and allows a newer conductor to assist older
compute nodes during upgrades to a significant degree.

Related-Bug: #1258256
Change-Id: I4b17c8382619e4f73b83c026bf68549ac67a68a2

(cherry picked from commit 69ce114232f9102220b45c8242eda3e78872a3e6)

Conflicts:
	cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py

commit_message:
LVM migrate: Use keywords for the brick instance

In the `migrate_volume` method a new instance is created when the
dest_vg is not equal to the source vg. This new brick instance is
created using positional arguments instead of keywords. However, some of
those arguments are passed in the wrong positions.

This patch uses keywords for the misplaced arguments.

The patch also changes `test_lvm_migrate_volume_proceed` in order to
fully test the happy path and catch things like this.

Closes-bug: #1258128
(cherry picked from commit 69ce114232f9102220b45c8242eda3e78872a3e6)

Conflicts:
	cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py

Change-Id: I75cf91171709554053fd5b52a4aae4e176e8364e

well, thanks for the co-author credit but I don't see much of my original work here. I'm sure what you've done is much better. I have a few comments and concerns. Mostly, I noticed that you didn't pull over the code that fixes the root cause of the path errors.

The path errors we saw at certain unnamed clients sites involved the path of the vmfolder.

Conceptually, all VMs in a vCenter are placed under a Datacenter and each datacenter has a vmfolder that holds all instances. The idea of a datacenter (at least conceptually) is that this represents a segregated hunk of hardware so when you ask about all virtual machines in a datacenter in Cleveland, it makes no sense to talk about the ones in Munich (as an exaggerated example nobody really does that).

So selecting the correct datacenter paths is pretty important. vmfolder happens to be an implicit and hidden path for VM placement specification even so, Nova must tell vCenter "the scheduler said place it here" where here is the vmfolder, datastore, etc. Since the current scheduler is only giving the datastore coordinate we can extrapolate which datacenter the scheduler meant by calculating the nearest in tree vmfolder path.

Currently the driver completely ignores all this and we tell people to just use one datacenter so that the calculation can't possibly get messed up (but more than one and the path calculation can be wrong) so this is a pretty major driver change we need to get right. 

We need to be sure that we encode the tree traversals correctly so that the scheduler's intentions are properly translated into vCenter commands. That's not happening right now.

I will pull this for manual testing later this week but I can tell by looking you'll still fail when there are more than one datacenter and the intended datacenter is not *first* or position 0.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-10-24 10:52:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-24 11:53:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

commit_message:
VMware: fix bug when more than one datacenter exists

In the case that there was more than one datacenter defined on the VC,
then spawning an instance would result in an exception. The reason for this
was that the nova compute would not set the correct datacenter for the
selected datastore.

The fix also takes care of the correct folder selection. This too was a
result of not selecting the correct folder for the data center.

The 'fake' configuration was updated to contain an additional data
center with its on datastore.

Closes-Bug: #1180044
Closes-Bug: #1214850

Co-authored-by: Shawn Harsock <hartsocks@vmware.com>

Change-Id: Ib61811fffcbc80385efc3166c9e366fdaa6432bd

subject: Normalize the weights instead of using raw values

have to ensure that all weights are normalized before doing anything

A couple of nits."}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-04-22 07:46:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-22 08:31:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-04-22 08:38:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Brian: You can use multiple, but you need to normalize them to make a meaningful weighting. If you do not normalize them, a huge value for one weight might mask the other weights. For example, the RAM weighter could be masked by a weighter based on the available disk space.

The phrase: "If somebody wants to implement any weighter different than RAM we have to ensure that all weights are normalized before doing anything with them" means that if we want weights to be really useful we need to normalize
them before applying the multiplicator and before adding them to the weighter object.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-04-22 14:52:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Hmm.  I can see why you're doing this, but the potential for one weight to mask another is a consequence of how weight multipliers get configured.

I don't feel strongly about this either way, but I do want to point out that this change will force operators to re-configure their weights.  I'm just not wholly convinced this buys anything worth breaking compatibility for?"}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-04-22 15:58:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Brian: Currently there is only one weighter in nova (RAM) so operators should not do anything extra since the ordering should be the same, normalized or using raw values.

With only multipliers you could handle the situation of one weighter masking another, but if we add more weighters the configuration will become far more complicated.

A quick and possibly innacurate example: if I want the RAM weighter to be two times more important that the disk space, it is not enough to put 2.0 as the multiplier, since the RAM magnitude (GB) can be shaded by some TB of disk space, so I have to calculate a proper multiplier. If I have these values normalized, its just setting 2.0 as a multiplier.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-04-22 17:02:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

All I was getting at is that although there is only one weight in the default tree, the system is designed to be pluggable so you can't really know what weight classes deployers are using.

Thanks for the explanation.  So the actual goal of this is to make the weight multiplier a more consistent "control knob" to influence the overall weight of an instance?  I'd be happy if it was more clear from the commit message what the goal of the patch is.  (The patch doesn't create any new feature, per se, it just makes using the multipliers easier.)'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-04-22 17:54:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Brian.

Thanks a lot for your comments.

"All I was getting at is that although there is only one weight in the default tree, the system is designed to be pluggable so you can't really know what weight classes deployers are using."

And that is why normalization is important. All the weighters can make whatever decision they want, but if we normalize we know that 1 is the best in his category, whereas 0 is the worst, so we can use multipliers to define the relative importance of a weight regarding the rest.

"Thanks for the explanation. So the actual goal of this is to make the weight multiplier a more consistent "control knob" to influence the overall weight of an instance? I'd be happy if it was more clear from the commit message what the goal of the patch is. (The patch doesn't create any new feature, per se, it just makes using the multipliers easier.)"

You're welcome. More or less, yes. Normalizing the weights to a known range of values (between 0 and 1 for instance) makes possible for a sysadmin to properly use the multipliers (that are weighting the weigths), so that it is possible to define the importance of a given weight regarding the others without further calculations. For example, I am working in a weighter that takes into account the cached images on a given host (1 is cached, 0 not cached). Without normalizing, I need to set up a huge multiplier to compete with the RAM weighter. If I introduce a node with a large amount of RAM in the system, I'd need to recalculate the multiplier, and so on...

I'll try to submit a better commit message, since I agree that it is a bit unclear.'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-04-23 08:51:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-23 09:41:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

Okay, so I'm sold on the general idea of restricting the range of weight values to avoid one weigher shadowing the affect of another.

I am, however, still confused about the math being done here in this patch:

Say I have 2 weighers that result in the following list of calculated weights:  w = [2,4].  The normalize() function here would turn into: wnorm = [0.0, 1.0]

Now suppose the 0.0 value in wnorm was associated with a weigher that had a  very high multiplier. (i.e. the thing being weighed is important to the deployer)
Wouldn't this result in the weight value of an "important" multiplier getting ignored?

If I'm missing something obvious, just let me know.  Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-04-24 07:52:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (4 inline comments)

Brian good point, but the behaviour is not as you described.

Each weighter returns a list of weighted objects with their raw weights. This list is normalized and then it is multiplied and added to the weighted object.

Say you have 3 objects, and 2 weighters. The first weighter gives you [1, 10, 20] and the second [1, 0, 0]. These values, normalized are (aprox) [0.0, 0.5, 1.0] and [1, 0, 0], so, with a multiplier of 1 for each weighter, the final weight will be [1.0, 0.5, 1.0]. If you put a multiplier of 2 for the second weighter, the final weight would be [2.0, 0.5, 1.0].'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-04-24 07:55:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-24 08:45:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

Sorry if I'm missing the point, but we have a use case where we do explicitly use different weight ranges for different weight functions.   We have some cases where for license reasons we need to group instances of certain types of images together regardless of a more optimal resource placement.

I'm not against providing for normaliation where it makes sense for people (maybe free ram and free disk could be normalised for example) but it must be possible to also specify functions which are not subject to normalisation, and I don't see that in here currently.   

(As a side note - would really like to see design changes like this going through some sort of blueprint approval rather than having to catch them in code review if possible)"}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-04-29 14:38:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

My point was that it only makes sense to normalize some of the weights - and from what I can see this change would normalise all of them.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-29 21:31:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

The only change I see in there at the moment is a block of deleted text"}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-04-30 13:49:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Brian, Matt: I will address your changes during this week, since currently I'm
traveling and cannot have a look into this.

Phil, some comments inline

Regarding: "Sorry if I'm missing the point, but we have a use case where we do explicitly use different weight ranges for different weight functions. We have some cases where for license reasons we need to group instances of certain types of images together regardless of a more optimal resource placement."

Sorry , but I cannot understand your point: what is the problem with
normalization here? If you want to "prioritise" your weight (because it is
important for you), you should use a high multiplier for it, instead of using
an artificially high weight. The final weight is computed like this:

    weight = w1_multiplier * normalize(w1) + w1_multiplier * normalize(w2)

So if w2 is more important that w1, simply putting a higher multiplier for w2
would do the job. However, if you are using raw weights, with a completely
unknown weight range for w1 it is difficult to configure it a priori, and you
probably should adjust it in the future, for example if w1 is RAM and you
change it.

From my point of view (and like many batch systems and schedulers do) it is
much clear and clean to use a normalized weight so that I can say "weight 1
should be twice important than weight 2" without knowing the weight
ranges a priori, and I cannot do this without normalizing them. 

Regarding: "I'm not against providing for normaliation where it makes sense for people (maybe free ram and free disk could be normalised for example) but it must be possible to also specify functions which are not subject to normalisation, and I don't see that in here currently."

You can do this, overriding the "weight_objects" in your weighter class,
exactly as it could be done before this change.

However, I can argue that this could even be allowed, since a bad designed
weighter could completely shade any other weighters. The weighter class can 
use whatever range it wants, but the scheduler should normalize before computing
the final weight for an object.

Regarding: "(As a side note - would really like to see design changes like this going through some sort of blueprint approval rather than having to catch them in code review if possible)"

I would try to do it during the week, but with the change and the code as it
is (i.e. with the RAM weighter), the behaviour is exactly the same.

Regarding: "My point was that it only makes sense to normalize some of the weights - and from what I can see this change would normalise all of them."

Could you please elaborate the reson for that statement? I cannot see a single 
situation that cannot be tackled using normalized weights + multipliers.
What is the problem of normalizing all the weights before applying the
multipliers and calculate the final weight for an object?'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-05-01 16:03:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Hi Alvaro,

Thanks for the reply - so it looks like I was partly right in that I may be missing something ;-)

I think what you're saying is that in effect this change forces every weighter function to implement a multiplier so that the user can change the priority wrt to other multipliers.    

I don't think that's an issue as such, but it needs to be documented and it would be good if it could somehow be enforced by the base class since just keeping the default _weight_multipler is now not a good option.

I also think we need a much clearer example of this, as the current example is in effect talked about as just a flag to revert the sort order rather than having a significance against other weight functions.

Keeping my -1 for now until the above are addresses  but tending towards a +1.    Thanks again for taking the time to work this through

Phil"}, {'account_id': 6450, 'date': '2013-05-02 10:33:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Hi Alvaro

I have a question about the way you calculate normalization. Wouldn't it be good to somehow (at least optionally be able to) specify the max/min values that the normalize function use instead of picking those from the list of values to be weighted.

If I have a weigher for a resource that ranges between 1 and 100 and normalize the weights of two objects, the normalization will produce equal results for weights that differ on the scale (as long as the same object has the highest weight).

For weights [0, 1], this will result in normalized values [0.0, 1.0].
For weights [99, 100] this will still result in the same [0.0, 1.0].

Lets assume I have two objects and two weighers. Both weighers produce values in the same range (this could possibly be already normalized values like utilization of resources which range from 0.0 to 1.0). The weighers give weights [0.1, 0.2] and [1.0, 0.1] which without further normalization gives final weights [1.1, 0.3]. With the current way of calculating normalization, the result will instead be [1.0, 1.0] which has an effect on the ordering of the objects."}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-05-02 14:32:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-10 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:
