Hi Brian.

Suppose you have 2 weighers and 2 objects. The first weigher returns [0.1, 0.2], and the second [10.0, 0.1].

 - If you do not apply normalization, the final weights for the objects will be [10.1, 0.3].

 - If you apply normalization without specifying a maximum value, you will get [1.0, 1.0], as it is the result of normalizing  [0.1, 0.2] into [0.0, 1.0] and [1.0, 0.1] into [1.0, 0.1] and summing them up.

 - If you apply normalization and specify a maximum value of 10.0 and a min of 0 for each of the weighers (note that it is something optional) you will get [1.01, 0.03]   0.11111111111111112]: it is the result of normalizing [0.1, 0.2] into [0.01, 0.02] and [10.0, 0.1] into [1.0, 0.01].


This example will show the above:


    from nova.weights import normalize

    weigher_1 = [0.1, 0.2]
    weigher_2 = [10.0, 0.1]

    total_weight = [0, 0]
    total_weight_norm = [0, 0]
    total_weight_norm_maxmin = [0, 0]
    for w in (weigher_1, weigher_2):
    for i, weight in enumerate(w):                
        total_weight[i] += weight

    for i, weight in enumerate(normalize(w)):
        total_weight_norm[i] += weight

    for i, weight in enumerate(normalize(w, maxval=10, minval=0)):
        total_weight_norm_maxmin[i] += weight

    print total_weight
    print total_weight_norm
    print total_weight_norm_maxmin


The range of values must be specified by the weigher itself, and it is intended for cases where not only the absolute position among the other weighed objects is important, but also the position in the whole weigher range.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-07-16 14:48:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks for the explanation.  I was thinking you only normalized the final sum of weights, but it makes more sense now.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-07-16 20:08:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

I am unclear on how this help specially when the deplyer will still have to tweak the min and max values for each weigher."}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-07-17 08:07:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (5 inline comments)

@Joe: "I am unclear on how this help specially when the deplyer will still have to tweak the min and max values for each weigher."

The deployer should never, ever specify the min and max values. It is only there for the developer of a weigher just in case they think it is useful and relevant for their weigher.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-07-17 21:45:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

My question is how are those options used in a way that the deployer doesn't have to worry about."}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-07-18 08:35:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

@Joe: Sorry, but I don't get your point.

The min/max values are only intended for a potential developer of a given weigher. If the developer thinks it is important to specify the range of possible values he could specify the min and max values (for example, if the weight is based on some percentage you should specify 0 and 100 as min and max values).

With Hans Lindgren comment on patch 8 in mind I am still a little confused about how the RAM filter should work normalized.

"I have a question about the way you calculate normalization. Wouldn't it be good to somehow (at least optionally be able to) specify the max/min values that the normalize function use instead of picking those from the list of values to be weighted.
If I have a weigher for a resource that ranges between 1 and 100 and normalize the weights of two objects, the normalization will produce equal results for weights that differ on the scale (as long as the same object has the highest weight)."  RAM sounds like a prime example of this.  you don't want to normalize relative to the current range of values, but  rather normalize relative to the absolute range of values.


At the very least I would like to see one implemented case using the min max options you added after Hans's comment.'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-07-24 10:57:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

I do not see clear case right now. You can know your ranges if you are developing a weigher that weigher that gives weights based on a percentage (or any weigher whose values are in a fixed range).

A quick example for the first case is a network bandwidth weigher, that will give values according to the current usage in a 0..100 range.

A more complicated example would be a weigher based on the image distribution and cached images. For example this weigher could return 0 if the image is not cached, 1 if it is cached in the node and 0.5 if it being downloaded in that moment (for example because another request has been just scheduled). In this case, specifying the range 0..1 makes sense.

Please note that these are really quick examples.'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-07-30 11:20:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-07-30 11:20:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I am still unclear on how this is supposed to work in the Ram filter example.

Lets say I have two machines with 100GB of memory each.  you set the minvalue to 0.  So if the amount of free memory is 10 and 20, these will be normalized to 1.0 and 0.5.  And if the amount of free memory is 20, and 30, these will be normalize to 1.0 and 0.666.   Even though 20GB is less then 30GB they normalize to the same values.


Can you please walk me through an example.'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-07-31 07:26:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

Giving weights to a list of objects is a way of prioritising with regard to a given metric (it can be the free RAM, the percentage of bandwidth used, if a node has a cached image and whatnot). Normalizing those weights is needed since otherwise it is quite difficult (if not impossible) for an operator to stablish the importance between the weighers if we are only using raw values.  For example, if we want to give a lot of importance to a weigher we should inflate artificially either the multiplier or the weight given to an object to shade the effect of the RAM weigher that returns RAW values. If the amount of RAM increases (for example a hardware upgrade) we have to adjust everything again. If the infrastructure is composed of heterogeneous hardware, it is even more difficult.

In most cases it is not important to stablish the theoretical upper limit of the list since you only want the winner of that list of objects (as in the RAM case). For example, in the RAM weigher we are focusing in the node with more RAM available, since we know that all the weighed hosts are able to allocate the needed memory for the request (they have been filtered well in advance). In this case, I do not see necessary at all to stablish the upper limit. The winner will be in all cases the node with more RAM available, regardless of the total amount of RAM (and I, being an operator, am quite happy with that behaviour).

The upper limit is only meaningful if the weigher is based in a percentage (the bandwidth example in my other comment) or unless the weigher returns always a fixed set of values (i.e. the second example in my other comment where the weigher returns 0, 0.5 and 1).'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-07-31 07:41:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-07-31 07:41:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Also why not just change all the existing weighers to produce normalized values themselves?  So a weigher must return a value between 0 and 1?"}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-08-01 07:12:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

Hi Joe.

I think it is time to move the discussion to the ML.

However, just some comments:

"Also I still don't understand the RAM example, no absolute max makes it harder to use along with other weighers."

With the code as it is, the RAM weigher has the same behaviour as without
normalization. Maybe I am missing something obvious to you, but why makes
it harder?

"Also why not just change all the existing weighers to produce normalized values themselves? So a weigher must return a value between 0 and 1?" 

IMHO I think it is better this approach since the weight developer only has to
take care of giving weights to the objects, regardless of the range of values.
I think it is a task of the weight handler to normalize the weights so that it
gets a consistent value for all of them, not leting this task to the weigher
itself. By doing so, we ensure that the scheduler is getting consistent results
even if somebody is using some contrib, 3rd party, weighers.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-09 06:03:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Abandoned

I looked back at the ML: "> With the current code, this is not true. Anyway, I think this responsability
> should be implemented in the BaseWeightHandler rather than each weigher.
> This way each weigher can return whatever they want, but we will be
> always using a correct value.

I think the problem with moving it to the base handler is that the base
doesn't know the max range of the value ... of course, this could be
passed down. But yeah, we wouldn't want to duplicate the normalization
code itself in every function.
"

And if I remember correctly the issue of the max value for the ram is still an issue.  It is something that a developer cannot know, only a deployer.  and your proposed solution doesn't address this'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-08-13 21:24:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

Excuse me Joe, but I don't get your point. Do we agree that normalization *is* necessary to the scheduler or not?

Regarding your last message: 

"And if I remember correctly the issue of the max value for the ram is still an issue. It is something that a developer cannot know, only a deployer. and your proposed solution doesn't address this"

Since all the weighted hosts have the needed amount of memory, we want to select the winner from a list of hosts, regardless of the total amount of RAM.  This is the behavior of the current weigher, and this is exactly the behavior of the modified RAM weigher in my change. If this is an issue, this is an issue with the RAM weigher itself, not with the normalization mechanism that my change is trying to address.

Moreover, why is this an even an issue? I agree that the RAM weigher should have a minimum value (as I implemented it in my change according to your request), but I do not see a reasonable reason to put a maximum value for it.

Lastly, as a deployer, I would not be happy if I have to manually set the maximum amount of RAM (and eventually CPU, and disk, and whatnot) for each of my zones or aggregates (not to say that it will be a pain to readjust it again whenever I upgrade my hardware).'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-13 21:39:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

"we want to select the winner from a list of hosts, regardless of the total amount of RAM" this is the part I am not convinced of.  I may want to say I want pick the machine that passes my filters, and has the largest % of free memory.  And I am afraid that the normalization code, will hide the fact that this isn't supported today.

The BP aims to address: "This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing the relative importance between two weighers (one big magnitude could shade a smaller one)." but because of the reason above  I don't think it does.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-21 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-21 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-08-27 08:42:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Restored'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-08-27 09:24:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

> "we want to select the winner from a list of hosts, regardless of the total amount of RAM"
> this is the part I am not convinced of. I may want to say I want pick the machine that
> passes my filters, and has the largest % of free memory.

I understand your position, but IMHO this is a problem with the RAM weigher, not with the normalization mechanism that I am trying to push.

This change aims to introduce normalization, preserving the behavior with the old weighers, so the modified RAM weigher provided along with this patch is consistent with the old behavior (i.e. select the host with more ram available, regardless if this RAM is a 10% of the node, or a 100%). The rest of the change (i.e. the normalization part, and the modified base weight handler) opens the door so that a *different* weigher can weight the hosts regarding the % or free RAM and it is finally properly normalized (the weigher can set the maximum absolute RAM reading the hosts' state). This is a different weigher that I am happy to code it if you want, but this is not related anyhow with normalization. With the weigher as it is right now in the master you have the very same problem (the upper limit of the weighted objects is open).

> And I am afraid that the normalization code, will hide the fact that this isn't supported today.

I don't understand what you want to expose here.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-28 16:47:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

I agree what we have now is not really usable, but I don't think this is a comprehensive enough fix to make it significantly easier for deployers / weigher developers.

> I don't understand what you want to expose here.

I don't want to normalize by default, only if a weigher specifically chooses to be normalized.  Because as discussed before blindly normalizing the return values isn't always enough.


Note: while it is still possible to get this into Havana there is not much time left.

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Havana_Release_Schedule"}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-08-29 09:49:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-08-29 10:06:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-19 09:29:42.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize the scheduler weights.

If somebody wants to implement any weighter different than RAM we
have to ensure that all weights are normalized before doing anything
with them (that is, before applying the multiplier and before we sum
the calculated weight to the object). In this change all the weights
are normalized to 1, so that the final weight for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm_w1 + w2_multiplier * norm_w2 + ...

DocImpact

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20
'}, {'created': '2013-04-19 12:49:27.000000000', 'message': "Normalize the scheduler weights.

The weighter was usint the raw values instead of normalizing them.
If somebody wants to implement any weighter different than RAM we
have to ensure that all weights are normalized before doing anything
with them (that is, before applying the multiplier and before we sum
the calculated weight to the object). In this change all the weights
are normalized to 1, so that the final weight for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm_w1 + w2_multiplier * norm_w2 + ...

The RAM weighter relied on setting the multiplier to -1 so as to make a
reverse ordering and this is no longer true, therefore another option
'ram_weight_inverse' has been added.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20
"}, {'created': '2013-04-23 08:51:51.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize the scheduler weights instead of using raw values.

Currently the weighter is using the raw values instead of normalizing
them. This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing
the relative importance between two wheigters (one big magnitude could
shade a smaller one).

This commit introduces weight normalization so that we can apply
multipliers easily. The commit does not change the behaviour per-se
since currently we only have 1 weighter. All the weights will be
normalized between 0.0 and 1.0, so that the final weight for a host
will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

Also, a new "ram_weight_inverse" flag has been introduced for the
RAMWeighter. Before, the weigther stated that to change the behaviour
to "stacking" instead of "spreading", a negative multiplier would do
the trick but this is not true when using more that one weighter.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20
'}, {'created': '2013-04-24 07:55:02.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize the scheduler weights instead of using raw values.

will be:

Also, a new "ram_weight_inverse" flag has been introduced for the

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20
'}, {'created': '2013-06-10 11:17:58.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize the scheduler weights instead of using raw values.

Currently the weight system is using the raw values instead of normalizing
them. This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing
the relative importance between two wheighers (one big magnitude could
shade a smaller one).

This commit introduces weight normalization so that we can apply
multipliers easily. All the weights for an object will be normalized
between 0.0 and 1.0 before being sumed up, so that the final weight
for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

Also, a new "ram_weight_inverse" flag has been introduced for the
RAMWeigher. Before, the weigher stated that to change the behaviour
to "stacking" instead of "spreading", a negative multiplier would do
the trick but this is not true when using more that one weigher.

Partially implements blueprint normalize-scheduler-weights
DocImpact

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20
'}, {'created': '2013-06-10 13:23:15.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize the weights instead of using raw values.

The weight system is being used by the scheduler and the cells code.

Currently the weight system is using the raw values instead of normalizing
them. This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing
the relative importance between two wheighers (one big magnitude could
shade a smaller one).

This commit introduces weight normalization so that we can apply
multipliers easily. All the weights for an object will be normalized
between 0.0 and 1.0 before being sumed up, so that the final weight
for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

The RAMWeigher and RamByInstanceTypeWeigher have been modified so as to
introduce a new "ram_weight_inverse" flag. Before, these weighers stated
that to change the behaviour to "stacking" instead of "spreading", a
negative multiplier would do the trick but this is not true when using
more that one weigher.

The MuteChildWeigher does not need anymore the 'mute_weight_value'.

Partially implements blueprint normalize-scheduler-weights
DocImpact

TODO: enforce the weighers to implement a multiplier.

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20
'}, {'created': '2013-07-02 14:03:41.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize the weights instead of using raw values.

The weight system is being used by the scheduler and the cells code.
Currently this system is using the raw values instead of normalizing them.
This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing the
relative importance between two wheighers (one big magnitude could
shade a smaller one).

Changes in this commit:

1) it introduces weight normalization so that we can apply multipliers
easily. All the weights for an object will be normalized between 0.0 and
1.0 before being sumed up, so that the final weight for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

2) RAMWeigher and RamByInstanceTypeWeigher have been modified so as to
introduce a new "ram_weight_inverse" flag. Before, these weighers stated
that to change the behaviour to "stacking" instead of "spreading", a
negative multiplier would do the trick but this is not true when using
more that one weigher.

3) weights.BaseWeighter has been changed into an ABC so that we enforce
that all weighers have the expceted methods.

4) Adapt the existing weighers to the above changes.

5) unittests for all of the above

Implements blueprint normalize-scheduler-weights
DocImpact

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20
'}, {'created': '2013-07-10 09:19:36.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize the weights instead of using raw values.

The weight system is being used by the scheduler and the cells code.
Currently this system is using the raw values instead of normalizing them.
This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing the
relative importance between two wheighers (one big magnitude could
shade a smaller one).

Changes in this commit:

1) it introduces weight normalization so that we can apply multipliers
easily. All the weights for an object will be normalized between 0.0 and
1.0 before being sumed up, so that the final weight for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

2) weights.BaseWeigher has been changed into an ABC so that we enforce
that all weighers have the expceted methods.

3) weights.BaseWeigher.weigh_objects() does no longer sum up the
computer weighs to the object, but it rather returns a list that will be
then normalized and added to the existing weight by BaseWeightHandler

4) Adapt the existing weighers to the above changes.

5) unittests for all of the above

Implements blueprint normalize-scheduler-weights
DocImpact

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20
'}, {'created': '2013-07-18 10:20:55.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize the weights instead of using raw values.

2) weights.BaseWeigher has been changed into an ABC so that we enforce

'}, {'created': '2013-07-19 07:19:36.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize the weights instead of using raw values.

The weight system is being used by the scheduler and the cells code.
Currently this system is using the raw values instead of normalizing them.
This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing the
relative importance between two wheighers (one big magnitude could
shade a smaller one).

Changes in this commit:

1) it introduces weight normalization so that we can apply multipliers
easily. All the weights for an object will be normalized between 0.0 and
1.0 before being sumed up, so that the final weight for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

2) weights.BaseWeigher has been changed into an ABC so that we enforce
that all weighers have the expected methods.

3) weights.BaseWeigher.weigh_objects() does no longer sum up the
computer weighs to the object, but it rather returns a list that will be
then normalized and added to the existing weight by BaseWeightHandler

4) Adapt the existing weighers to the above changes.

5) unittests for all of the above

Implements blueprint normalize-scheduler-weights
DocImpact

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20

'}, {'created': '2013-09-05 11:23:58.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize the weights instead of using raw values

The weight system is being used by the scheduler and the cells code.
Currently this system is using the raw values instead of normalizing them.
This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing the
relative importance between two wheighers (one big magnitude could
shade a smaller one). This change introduces weight normalization so
that:

- From an operator point of view we can prioritize the weighers that
we are applying. The only way to do this is being sure that all the
weighers will give a value in a known range, so that it is
not needed to artificially use a huge multiplier to prioritize a
weigher.

- From a weigher developer point of view, somebody willing to implement
one has to care about 1) returning a list of values, 2) setting the
minimum and maximum values where the weights can range, if they are
needed and they are significant for the weighing. For a weigher
developer there are two use cases

 Case 1: Use of a percentage instead of absolute values (for example, %
 of free RAM). If we compare two nodes focusing on the percentage of free
 ram, the maximum value for the weigher is 100. If we have two nodes one
 with 2048 total/1024 free, and the second one 1024 total/512 free they
 will get both the same weight, since they have the same % of free RAM
 (that is, the 50%).

 Case 2: Use of absolute values. In this case, the maximum of the weigher
 will be the maximum of the values in the list (in the case above, 1024)
 or the maximum value that the magnitude could take (in the case above,
 2048). How this maximum is set, is a decision of the developer. He may
 let the operator choose the behaviour of the weigher though.

- From the point of view of the scheduler we ensure that it is using
normalized values, and not leveraging the normalization mechanism to the
weighers.

Changes introduced this commit:

1) it introduces weight normalization so that we can apply multipliers
easily. All the weights for an object will be normalized between 0.0 and
1.0 before being sumed up, so that the final weight for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

2) weights.BaseWeigher has been changed into an ABC so that we enforce
that all weighers have the expected methods.

3) weights.BaseWeigher.weigh_objects() does no longer sum up the
computer weighs to the object, but it rather returns a list that will be
then normalized and added to the existing weight by BaseWeightHandler

4) Adapt the existing weighers to the above changes.

5) unittests for all of the above

Implements blueprint normalize-scheduler-weights
DocImpact

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20

'}, {'created': '2013-11-11 16:42:11.000000000', 'message': "Normalize the weights instead of using raw values

The weight system is being used by the scheduler and the cells code.
Currently this system is using the raw values instead of normalizing them.
This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing the
relative importance between two wheighers (one big magnitude could
shade a smaller one). This change introduces weight normalization so
that:

- From an operator point of view we can prioritize the weighers that
  we are applying. The only way to do this is being sure that all the
  weighers will give a value in a known range, so that it is
  not needed to artificially use a huge multiplier to prioritize a
  weigher.

- From a weigher developer point of view, somebody willing to implement
  one has to care about 1) returning a list of values, 2) setting the
  minimum and maximum values where the weights can range, if they are
  needed and they are significant for the weighing. For a weigher
  developer there are two use cases:

    Case 1: Use of a percentage instead of absolute values (for example, %
    of free RAM). If we compare two nodes focusing on the percentage of free
    ram, the maximum value for the weigher is 100. If we have two nodes one
    with 2048 total/1024 free, and the second one 1024 total/512 free they
    will get both the same weight, since they have the same % of free RAM
    (that is, the 50%).

    Case 2: Use of absolute values. In this case, the maximum of the weigher
    will be the maximum of the values in the list (in the case above, 1024)
    or the maximum value that the magnitude could take (in the case above,
    2048). How this maximum is set, is a decision of the developer. He may
    let the operator choose the behaviour of the weigher though.

- From the point of view of the scheduler we ensure that it is using
  normalized values, and not leveraging the normalization mechanism to the
  weighers.

Changes introduced this commit:

1) it introduces weight normalization so that we can apply multipliers
   easily. All the weights for an object will be normalized between 0.0 and
   1.0 before being sumed up, so that the final weight for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

2) weights.BaseWeigher has been changed into an ABC so that we enforce
   that all weighers have the expected methods.

3) weights.BaseWeigher.weigh_objects() does no longer sum up the
   computer weighs to the object, but it rather returns a list that will be
   then normalized and added to the existing weight by BaseWeightHandler

4) Adapt the existing weighers to the above changes. Namely
    - New 'offset_weight_multiplier' for the cell weigher
      nova.cells.weights.weight_offset.WeightOffsetWeigher
    - Changed

5) unittests for all of the introduced changes.

Implements blueprint normalize-scheduler-weights
DocImpact: Now weights for an object are normalized before suming them
up. New configuration option (multiplier) for
nova.cells.weights.weight_offset.WeightOffsetWeigher

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20

Implements blueprint normalize-scheduler-weights

DocImpact: Now weights for an object are normalized before suming them
up. This means that each weigher will take a maximum value of 1. This
may have an impact for operators that are using more than one weigher
(currently there is only one weigher: RAMWeiger) and for operators using
cells (where we have several weighers). It is needed to review then the
multipliers used and adjust them properly in case they have been
modified.

Docimpact: There is a new configuration option 'offset_weight_multiplier'
in nova.cells.weights.weight_offset.WeightOffsetWeigher

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20
"}, {'created': '2013-12-08 21:15:05.000000000', 'message': "Normalize the weights instead of using raw values

The weight system is being used by the scheduler and the cells code.
Currently this system is using the raw values instead of normalizing them.
This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing the
relative importance between two wheighers (one big magnitude could
shade a smaller one). This change introduces weight normalization so
that:

- From an operator point of view we can prioritize the weighers that
  we are applying. The only way to do this is being sure that all the
  weighers will give a value in a known range, so that it is
  not needed to artificially use a huge multiplier to prioritize a
  weigher.

- From a weigher developer point of view, somebody willing to implement
  one has to care about 1) returning a list of values, 2) setting the
  minimum and maximum values where the weights can range, if they are
  needed and they are significant for the weighing. For a weigher
  developer there are two use cases:

    Case 1: Use of a percentage instead of absolute values (for example, %
    of free RAM). If we compare two nodes focusing on the percentage of free
    ram, the maximum value for the weigher is 100. If we have two nodes one
    with 2048 total/1024 free, and the second one 1024 total/512 free they
    will get both the same weight, since they have the same % of free RAM
    (that is, the 50%).

    Case 2: Use of absolute values. In this case, the maximum of the weigher
    will be the maximum of the values in the list (in the case above, 1024)
    or the maximum value that the magnitude could take (in the case above,
    2048). How this maximum is set, is a decision of the developer. He may
    let the operator choose the behaviour of the weigher though.

- From the point of view of the scheduler we ensure that it is using
  normalized values, and not leveraging the normalization mechanism to the
  weighers.

Changes introduced this commit:

1) it introduces weight normalization so that we can apply multipliers
   easily. All the weights for an object will be normalized between 0.0 and
   1.0 before being sumed up, so that the final weight for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

2) weights.BaseWeigher has been changed into an ABC so that we enforce
   that all weighers have the expected methods.

3) weights.BaseWeigher.weigh_objects() does no longer sum up the
   computer weighs to the object, but it rather returns a list that will be
   then normalized and added to the existing weight by BaseWeightHandler

4) Adapt the existing weighers to the above changes. Namely
    - New 'offset_weight_multiplier' for the cell weigher
      nova.cells.weights.weight_offset.WeightOffsetWeigher
    - Changed the name of the existing multiplier methods.

5) unittests for all of the introduced changes.

Implements blueprint normalize-scheduler-weights

DocImpact: Now weights for an object are normalized before suming them
up. This means that each weigher will take a maximum value of 1. This
may have an impact for operators that are using more than one weigher
(currently there is only one weigher: RAMWeiger) and for operators using
cells (where we have several weighers). It is needed to review then the
multipliers used and adjust them properly in case they have been
modified.

Docimpact: There is a new configuration option 'offset_weight_multiplier'
in nova.cells.weights.weight_offset.WeightOffsetWeigher

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20

commit_message:
Normalize the weights instead of using raw values

The weight system is being used by the scheduler and the cells code.
Currently this system is using the raw values instead of normalizing them.
This makes difficult to properly use multipliers for establishing the
relative importance between two wheighers (one big magnitude could
shade a smaller one). This change introduces weight normalization so
that:

- From an operator point of view we can prioritize the weighers that
  we are applying. The only way to do this is being sure that all the
  weighers will give a value in a known range, so that it is
  not needed to artificially use a huge multiplier to prioritize a
  weigher.

- From a weigher developer point of view, somebody willing to implement
  one has to care about 1) returning a list of values, 2) setting the
  minimum and maximum values where the weights can range, if they are
  needed and they are significant for the weighing. For a weigher
  developer there are two use cases:

    Case 1: Use of a percentage instead of absolute values (for example, %
    of free RAM). If we compare two nodes focusing on the percentage of free
    ram, the maximum value for the weigher is 100. If we have two nodes one
    with 2048 total/1024 free, and the second one 1024 total/512 free they
    will get both the same weight, since they have the same % of free RAM
    (that is, the 50%).

    Case 2: Use of absolute values. In this case, the maximum of the weigher
    will be the maximum of the values in the list (in the case above, 1024)
    or the maximum value that the magnitude could take (in the case above,
    2048). How this maximum is set, is a decision of the developer. He may
    let the operator choose the behaviour of the weigher though.

- From the point of view of the scheduler we ensure that it is using
  normalized values, and not leveraging the normalization mechanism to the
  weighers.

Changes introduced this commit:

1) it introduces weight normalization so that we can apply multipliers
   easily. All the weights for an object will be normalized between 0.0 and
   1.0 before being sumed up, so that the final weight for a host will be:

    weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

2) weights.BaseWeigher has been changed into an ABC so that we enforce
   that all weighers have the expected methods.

3) weights.BaseWeigher.weigh_objects() does no longer sum up the
   computer weighs to the object, but it rather returns a list that will be
   then normalized and added to the existing weight by BaseWeightHandler

4) Adapt the existing weighers to the above changes. Namely
    - New 'offset_weight_multiplier' for the cell weigher
      nova.cells.weights.weight_offset.WeightOffsetWeigher
    - Changed the name of the existing multiplier methods.

5) unittests for all of the introduced changes.

Implements blueprint normalize-scheduler-weights

DocImpact: Now weights for an object are normalized before suming them
up. This means that each weigher will take a maximum value of 1. This
may have an impact for operators that are using more than one weigher
(currently there is only one weigher: RAMWeiger) and for operators using
cells (where we have several weighers). It is needed to review then the
multipliers used and adjust them properly in case they have been
modified.

Docimpact: There is a new configuration option 'offset_weight_multiplier'
in nova.cells.weights.weight_offset.WeightOffsetWeigher

Change-Id: I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20

commit_message:
Use nosetests for coverage in tox.ini

I can't seem to figure out how to have testr and coverage working
properly without pbr so let's use nosetests for it.

Yes we have been around this one before. Using the current federation design, it is perfectly possible to treat Apache as the trusted IDP, and define a new protocol (say HTTP) in which the identity attributes are carried in the header. Then everything else will work just fine. You will still need to set up your trusted IDP rules, trusted attribute issuing rules, and trusted mapping rules though. the only bit that will change is the protocol dependent module that will validate the HTTP request instead of a SAML assertion'}, {'account_id': 994, 'date': '2013-12-11 23:25:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Add IdP management extension (Federation pt1)

Add an extension to manage IdPs, this is required for adding federation
support to keystone.

Co-Authored-By: Kristy Siu <kwss@kent.ac.uk>
Co-Authored-By: David Chadwick <d.w.chadwick@kent.ac.uk>
Co-Authored-By: Joe Savak <jsavak@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Marek Denis <marek.denis@cern.ch>
Co-Authored-By: Dolph Mathews <dolph.mathews@gmail.com>

Implements: blueprint virtual-idp
Change-Id: I783d85748d4c051ee685a5b54a824a7d461e1860

commit_message:
Align with global requirements & use pbr in setup.py

Aligns our test requirements & requirements files with global
dependencies. The exception is celery, which is still listed
as a dependency while we investigate oslo-messaging.

python-dateutil and psycopg2 were removed as they are not hard
dependencies

Change-Id: Ia0370e18391030f0c3b541921dbf00698a45e9ad

commit_message:
Remove notifier_strategy config from glance-api

Glance now uses notification_driver. See Glance commit
90d6ef8130fd7e121e35221eb1452e6646ba4047 or change ID:

 I8cd84772bc5867e06b2a50ed7e15b9e86f0b94ad

Since the default value for notification_driver is noop
we just removed it.

Change-Id: I1eab3d4f7b0ccfe428a22be4d5553f6503ddf0aa

52-force-text-mode-console, running after 51-bootloader, calls

This call will overwrite all the changes that 51-bootloader did to the

Change-Id: Ida8e1a69df22d41ad70eb7154707c50613b536a8
'}]
commit_message:
Merge force-text-mode-console into the bootloader script

52-force-text-mode-console, running after 51-bootloader, calls
grub2-mkconfig (on Ubuntu that will happen via the update-grub call).
This call will overwrite all the changes that 51-bootloader did to the
grub.cfg. By merging the 52-force-text-mode-console code into
51-bootloader we avoid that. This also means that 51-bootloader will now
call grub2-mkconfig regardless of whether there is already and existing
grub2 configuration or not (52-force-text-mode-console did that in the
past anyway).

Additionally this commit enables the force to textmode code for openSUSE
(was previously only working correctly for Ubuntu and Fedora).

Closes-Bug: #1260323
Change-Id: Ida8e1a69df22d41ad70eb7154707c50613b536a8

commit_message:
Fix cinder element to make volumes persistent

The element's os-refresh-config script was failing because
/var/run/cinder does not exist. It does not exist because /var/run
is usually tmpfs or cleared out before boot proceeds.

Closes-Bug: #1261403
Change-Id: Ic7042728e64159c83431c11eb1ab1bba6e7e656c

commit_message:
Added missing Neutron package install command for Ubuntu

In the Neutron installation documentation for a dedicated controller
node, there's missing entries for installing on a Ubuntu based
system.

Added the change for Debian also.

Change-Id: Ia30381eca87af273904f3608dc92f519a8ed6741
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1261155
(cherry picked from commit 88400370464d8fd465ee174751616ff7d0ce31c1)

commit_message:
Install Guide: cinder setup for ceilometer fixes

* openstack-cinder-volume should be restarted, not
  openstack-cinder-agent-central
* use 'ceilometer' instead of 'cinder' in the section id

Change-Id: Id9cbab26ed8aa9d09b98da93576ff7aad8c304b7
Closes-Bug: #1259456
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit ed3357982cb994d730adb381b1313f3762335c23)

commit_message:
Make parameter doc RDoc compatible

This patch fixes the parameter documentation in
init, and conductor to conform with the style guide
and support autogenerating parameter documentation.

Change-Id: I737e8d0716a21795575558e65a135fd488c814c0

commit_message:
Make parameter doc RDoc compatible

This patch fixes all remaining parameter documentation
in the nova module to be compatible with puppet-doc
and documents all parameters in a standard way.

Change-Id: I451078d46cb2498dd8e3c23bd8cbcc81b8845fcd

commit_message:
Adds included-template-dir param for resolving template FileIncludes

In I587fa7a826f93f89e8e5c266af7f5765438fe738 there is a problem with
the overcloud.yaml Make target. Once the merge.py script is moved from
where the templates are, FileInclude paths cannot be resolved relative
to the script. The included-template-path defaults to './'

Change-Id: I220c5e52d8062e98aa28a1c582e29c7e844bc9ae

commit_message:
Change default case nic in post_install_network_config_fuel

Removes long wait times in centos on first boot when devices are left
 in DHCP mode and have to wait for timeout.

Resolves-bug #1260879

Change-Id: Iaf4f2fa55ba96cc9298cad02a67e2309c74e9cb6

commit_message:
Move Fake objects to a special tests.fakes module

A set of Fake objects originally created for nova scenarios unit tests
turned out to be very useful for several other unit tests as well. Here,
we move all these Fake objects to a special tests.fakes module. This will
also simplify code reuse in future unit tests.

Blueprint unit-tests-refactoring

Change-Id: I2b3c6a3f1543a186fe498d886e3fd4bfe615dce8

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-15 18:30:25.000000000', 'message': 'Move admin client initialization into stress-openstack

Running the stress test framework without any tempest.conf causes
an error. This is due to the fact that the admin client expects the
configuration file. This causes error while doing pep8 checks (see
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/56308/)

Pin sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error:

  error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name (got `...doc/source`)

See: http://bugs.python.org/issue19570
and: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/pull-request/193/builddoc-shouldnt-fail-on-unicode-paths/diff

Change-Id: I69b3d83185d1b144474314402ad5449980d6ffbc
Co-Authored-By: "James E. Blair" <jeblair@openstack.org>
Co-Authored-By: Marc Koderer <m.koderer@telekom.de>
Fixes: bug #1251663
'}]
commit_message:
Move admin client initialization into stress-openstack

Running the stress test framework without any tempest.conf causes
an error. This is due to the fact that the admin client expects the
configuration file. This causes error while doing pep8 checks (see
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/56308/)

Pin sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error:

  error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name (got `...doc/source`)

See: http://bugs.python.org/issue19570
and: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/pull-request/193/builddoc-shouldnt-fail-on-unicode-paths/diff

Change-Id: I69b3d83185d1b144474314402ad5449980d6ffbc
Co-Authored-By: "James E. Blair" <jeblair@openstack.org>
Co-Authored-By: Marc Koderer <m.koderer@telekom.de>
Fixes: bug #1251663

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-03 19:33:43.000000000', 'message': "Update common network type consts to same origin

This patch removes new definitions of common network type constants (TYPE_FLAT,
TYPE_LOCAL, etc.) and modifies uses of aforementioned constants to a common
place where constants are defined (neutron.plugins.common.constants). This
patch does not change values that are equal in value but different in name:
NETWORK_TYPE_FLAT vs TYPE_FLAT. A second changeset will be made to handle that
case.

Unit tests were modified as well when they referred to the constant.

Finally, the ovs agent code refers to the OVS plugin constants directly and
these had to be changed as well. A TODO flag was put in that file due to use
of another plugin specific constant.

Network types that were only defined in a single plugin, such as mellanox's
infiniband (IB) network type was not carried over to the common constants file.

Fixes-bug: #1196170

Change-Id: Ib6bfc8275496a24bf247946d177c734b62ae44bb
"}, {'created': '2013-09-09 16:39:48.000000000', 'message': "Update common network type consts to same origin

NETWORK_TYPE_FLAT vs TYPE_FLAT. A second changeset will be made to handle that
case.

Unit tests were modified as well when they referred to the constant.

Finally, the ovs agent code refers to the OVS plugin constants directly and
these had to be changed as well. A TODO flag was put in that file due to use
of another plugin specific constant.

Network types that were only defined in a single plugin, such as mellanox's
infiniband (IB) network type was not carried over to the common constants file.

Fixes-bug: #1196170

Change-Id: Ib6bfc8275496a24bf247946d177c734b62ae44bb

commit_message:
Update common network type consts to same origin

This patch removes new definitions of common network type constants (TYPE_FLAT,
TYPE_LOCAL, etc.) and modifies uses of aforementioned constants to a common
place where constants are defined (neutron.plugins.common.constants). This
patch does not change values that are equal in value but different in name:
NETWORK_TYPE_FLAT vs TYPE_FLAT. A second changeset will be made to handle that
case.

Unit tests were modified as well when they referred to the constant.

Finally, the ovs agent code refers to the OVS plugin constants directly and
these had to be changed as well. A TODO flag was put in that file due to use
of another plugin specific constant.

Network types that were only defined in a single plugin, such as mellanox's
infiniband (IB) network type was not carried over to the common constants file.

Fixes-bug: #1196170

Change-Id: Ib6bfc8275496a24bf247946d177c734b62ae44bb

commit_message:
Export OS_SVC_ENABLE_CONTROl in upstart jobs

Without this export os-svc-enable.conf never sees the starting event and
thus never does anything to prevent starting the job.

Change-Id: Ib94c817ce3f2e6c3aada1515beea6e7fb41605af

commit_message:
Fix os-svc-daemon missing env in upstart jobs

Recent changes landed to set the environment variable
OS_SVC_ENABLE_CONTROL=1 but the env statement was left out, rendering
the upstart job completely broken as the syntax is now invalid.

Change-Id: I88a7a63304d1fe759067e47e2fab88ee27f91914

commit_message:
create os-image-upload role and change the order of
os-image-api and os-image-registry roles.

Create a new role os-image-upload and change the execution order of
os-image-api and os-image-registry roles in os-image role to make sure
the os-image-api role is executed before os-image-registry role since
glance db_sync use the sql_connection value in
/etc/glance/glance-api.conf.
Add os-image-upload to infrastructure.yml.
Remove the image_upload attribute from environments.

Change-Id: I218b52e1fd0ca68849e6aebd8bac6d8878790fba
Closes-Bug: #1257169

'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2013-10-07 23:33:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In reviewing the link to the neutron commit, it appears that they may be backtracking on removing auto generation.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-10-07 23:51:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Chris: Over the years several OpenStack projects have started out doing autogeneration and eventually moved towards some sort of DB tool to do it (glance db_sync, nova db sync, etc). The autogeneration has always ended up causing some sort of race/problem or something.

I think they guys on that branch may have stalled out a bit to give us time to do this (Firestack support). If there is a good reason not to remove autogeneration (in upstream neutron) I'd be interested in hearing what it is."}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2013-10-07 23:57:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I don't have an opinion against the change. I wanted to be sure the module tracked the patch you mentioned, or if the neutron autogen didn't go away, that nothing would be broken or inconsistent."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-10-08 01:30:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Chris: Cool. Should be safe for this to land regardless of the upstream neutron change. It shouldn't break anything and is arguably a better way to init the DB anyway.

Also, having it in ahead of time would be ideal for SmokeStack anyway."}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2013-10-08 21:42:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2013-10-11 20:49:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-10-15 17:22:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

Is puppet-neutron master still targeting Havana?
Is this change targeted at Icehouse?

We should avoid mixing changes until puppet-neutron for Havana is released.

Furthermore, I see a lot of open/ongoing discussions around this change in neutron. I would prefer this change to not land in puppet-neutron until it's merged upstream."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-10-15 19:00:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Mathieu,

As far as I know puppet-neutron (master) targets neutron (master). At all times. Meaning this would now target Icehouse. We should go ahead and create a stable branch for Havana.

Like I mentioned before though, there is no harm in doing this now (and it is arguably a better way to initialize the DB anyway). Some of the dev tools (devstack) already do the same.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-10-16 13:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Puppet-openstack#Branches

"The master branch of each modules corresponds to the master branch of the current OpenStack core projects. Once released, a new branch will be created and should be considered stable."'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-10-21 16:42:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

'}, {'account_id': 1926, 'date': '2013-10-29 14:38:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

looks good to me, I have one suggestion though, could we add a switch to toggle it off for users who don't want it (or use the enabled flag), specifically in my case I think this would break where I generate disk images, as I am using the puppet modules to install packages but the database isn't available.

nova does this with
$sync_db           = true,

and glance
$enabled           = true"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-10-29 18:13:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-10-29 18:14:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Derek: I made it so that if $enabled == false the db migrations won't run. Test included..."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-10-29 18:14:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Run neutron-db-manage upgrade.

Updates the neutron module so that it creates the database schema
before starting neutron-server and any associated plugins.

See this (pending) neutron commit:

 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/40296/

NOTE: Some of the dev tools already take this approach as well.

Change-Id: Ibb135fbd3e722ee89ef6ed6329baa5a4a90daf95

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-14 13:59:56.000000000', 'message': "Missing LVM package install step on Ubuntu and Debian

The Cinder Block Storage service node guide was missing a
step to install the lvm2 packages. These packages needed
to be installed before the pvcreate and vgcreate steps
were initiated.

Also fixes an bug that hasn't already been reported
as far as I can see. The Ubuntu and Debian versions of
this page go from Step 1 to Step 3 without a Step 2.

http://docs.openstack.org/havana/install-guide/install/apt-debian/content/cinder-node.html

Change-Id: I7b85b962f8652667dd9df18b470430f9063a89f8
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1259443

commit_message:
Missing LVM package install step on Ubuntu

The Cinder Block Storage service node guide was missing a
step to install the lvm2 packages. These packages needed
to be installed before the pvcreate and vgcreate steps
were initiated.

Change-Id: I7b85b962f8652667dd9df18b470430f9063a89f8
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1259443

commit_message:
use builtin bash getopts

Don't use /usr/bin/getopt which can change between platform (i.e: bsd
and gnu) this would drop the long argument features for sake of
portability.

Closes-Bug: 1261370
Change-Id: I821f1394672fec0262842f1a69e6b09c7f7a97fa

commit_message:
Modify the Case Study name to represent content

The case studies in the Security Guide are all provided with
a basic chapter title of "Case Study". There's no clarity as
to which chapter they represent. For readability and usability
this should be updated so that both the index and document
content are accurate.

Change-Id: Id27f8512c26189ce9e2edbf6f605692e581bcddc
Closes-Bug: 1248918

[{'created': '2013-12-16 00:56:35.000000000', 'message': 'Added Tenant-Create step to Create Base Networks

As reported to Launchpad, the creation of the base networks
document expects the user to create one or more initial tenants.
Whilst this has been done in prior steps, it's not clear, or
obvious how to do it. I've added a basic one-liner and linked
to relevant supporting documents in the install-guide.

Changes also fix a minor typo and append the "--tenant-id"
parameter to the user input sections where required.

Change-Id: I8ef3d3c69a5b10a9a4906f4249da1605f9a01e4c
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1261165
'}]
commit_message:
Added Tenant-Create step to Create Base Networks

As reported to Launchpad, the creation of the base networks
document expects the user to create one or more initial tenants.
Whilst this has been done in prior steps, it's not clear, or
obvious how to do it. I've added a basic one-liner and linked
to relevant supporting documents in the install-guide.

Changes also fix a minor typo and append the "--tenant-id"
parameter to the user input sections where required.

Change-Id: I8ef3d3c69a5b10a9a4906f4249da1605f9a01e4c
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1261165

commit_message:
Add one more slave to the ceph test

To get possible instance creation in verification
add 1 slave to the ceph tests

Also change update disk value
to avaid unallocated space, because by default we
have 50 Gb on each slave

Change-Id: Ibd7ad3b38ce1e8bad3cd928047f04d4c8cc8d47e
Closes-Bug: bug #1260677

commit_message:
Add ostf failed tests names and meesages in assert

In case if tests failed in method assert_ostf_run
there is no quick way to understand what exectly fail

Add failed_test_names variable,
that populated by failed ostf test names and error message
in assertTrue method. Value on this variable
will show only if AssertTrue fail.

Change-Id: Ib4475835c129a3240b9f3c270a3aa8de3d12a966

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-15 21:12:30.000000000', 'message': 'Glance: make logging configurable...

Adds top level glance.debug and glance.verbose config parameters
to control Glance logging.

As part of this change we are also:

 - Dropping --debug from the service config files. This cause the
  previous Glance log configuration to always log at the DEBUG level.

 - Remove the logging.conf file. The previous log file was also set
  to log at a DEBUG level. To get the same effect you can now
  just enable verbose/debug.

 - Drop --log-config from the service config files. We do this because
  we are dropping logging.conf.

 - Remove log_file from glance-api.conf and glance-registry.conf. This
  gives us the same behaviour as before where Glance logged using the
  init system logger.

The motivation for this change is primarily two things:

1) Glance should log at the WARNING level by default in production.
 (Not DEBUG as it did previously)

2) When making use of this element for CI we may want to more easily
 control the log level (and default to DEBUG). Using the new
 glance.debug and glance.verbose element parameters will make this
 easier.

Change-Id: I20e83682af0a46e455ba8f216bbd5e2f1e04ec16
'}]
commit_message:
Glance: make logging configurable...

Adds top level glance.debug and glance.verbose config parameters
to control Glance logging.

As part of this change we are also:

 - Dropping --debug from the service config files. This cause the
  previous Glance log configuration to always log at the DEBUG level.

 - Remove the logging.conf file. The previous log file was also set
  to log at a DEBUG level. To get the same effect you can now
  just enable verbose/debug.

 - Drop --log-config from the service config files. We do this because
  we are dropping logging.conf.

 - Remove log_file from glance-api.conf and glance-registry.conf. This
  gives us the same behaviour as before where Glance logged using the
  init system logger.

The motivation for this change is primarily two things:

1) Glance should log at the WARNING level by default in production.
 (Not DEBUG as it did previously)

2) When making use of this element for CI we may want to more easily
 control the log level (and default to DEBUG). Using the new
 glance.debug and glance.verbose element parameters will make this
 easier.

Change-Id: I20e83682af0a46e455ba8f216bbd5e2f1e04ec16

commit_message:
Add test with enabled ceilometer in deployment

Test includes:
* Deployment of simple cluster with 3 slaves
* Assert that api is running
* Run ostf tests (without revert)

Change-Id: Ib6379384902027d8eb0d76430c17ccd90a7ed101

'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-07-03 16:47:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Phil,
the idea seems very good to me. 
But I would prefer have the defaults set to 0 to not change the current behavior.
Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-07-03 16:51:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I think that changing the behavior is OK in this case.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-03 17:25:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

How about a default of 0 for delete (which I can see an argument for) and 120 for stop (where it really seems more likely you'd always want a clean shutdown) ?

That would also help with testing"}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-07-04 09:07:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Phil,
in fact what would be great is the support for "hard", "soft" in the api (v3?) for these operations. And then "soft" with timeouts.

I don't have a strong objection to have 120s for the "stop". But for "delete" seems more natural 0s as default.
Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-04 09:13:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-04 09:18:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I agree about adding hard and soft options to the API calls - but I'm going to leave those for a separate patch.   Defaults in this new patch are "soft" for stop and "hard" for delete which seems a reasonable compromise for now'}, {'account_id': 7138, 'date': '2013-07-04 09:44:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-04 10:26:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Code looks good. Some minor nits'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-07-08 12:54:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I really think we need to think about the semantics of this change. I'm ok with this on soft_reboot, mixed on power_off, but in destroy I'm definitely opposed. Destroy is a right now, kill it, don't let it damage anything more. Waiting for safe shutdown there when a guest might be the one doing the damage to other resources just doesn't seem ok."}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-07-08 14:11:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Agree with Sean. soft_reboot is ok because it is an api option. Why not add the same hard/soft parameter to shutdown and leave destroy alone?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-07-08 14:19:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I think the point of the graceful destroy is that if we're going to support restoring after a soft delete, we don't want to hard kill the guest and potentially corrupt its disk, right? This doesn't seem unreasonable to me, FWIW."}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-07-08 14:28:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'd much rather see this as a common approach between all hypervisors, rather than each hypervisor having a different (or code-copied) approach for shutting down the guests.

For example, something similar is in review for XenAPI: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/34031/.

I think as a minimum the timeouts need to be generically available so we don't end up with having to set different options to mean the same thing depending on the hypervisor"}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-07-08 14:33:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

We are not objecting to a capability to have a graceful shutdown. But a user should still be able to "pull the plug" if required. The parameters controlling this behaviour should be in an api like with reboot, not a global config.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-08 16:17:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Bob:  I don't seem to be able to see that Xen patch"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-08 16:23:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

As I mentioned in one or my earlier responses I'm not against adding "soft/hard" options to the API, but as the current (hard) behavior is currently leading to issues for users with unexpected guest file system corruptions  I was hoping that we could fix that directly with a better (IMO) set of defaults (stop=soft, delete=hard) with an option to configure different defaults and then add in the additional options as a second step.'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-07-08 16:26:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Sorry Phil - spurious period at the end of the URL! https://review.openstack.org/#/c/34031/'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-07-08 16:38:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Phil, fair enough.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-07-08 22:05:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Ok, so instead of having soft_reboot, stop, and destroy separate timeouts (and all libvirt specific) could we settle on 2 more generic variables.

soft_kill_timeout
hard_kill_timeout

(or something)

Destroy is a hard kill, reboot and stop are soft kill. They could be used equivalently in other hypervisors. It would also prevent us from having to grow these constants other places as well. I just fear having a world where every operation has a separate tunable on it, which raises all kinds of bugs as people mess with them.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-09 14:38:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

When we get to the point where we have the stop and delete behavior defined by the user via the API then we'll only need one configuration value (how log to wait for a soft shutdown).

If everyone is happy in making stop go to a "soft" model by default in the meantime then we could have just two values:

reboot_stop_shutdown_timeout  (default 120)
delete_shutdown_timeout (default 0)'}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2013-07-09 21:02:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

As long as you are making this more like the reboot API, could you add the 'type' argument to the whole process? That way people that need an immediate shutdown can send type=hard to the API and we kill things quickly."}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2013-07-09 21:07:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

I need to read all the comments before commenting myself :-). Looks like my point has already been made and discussed quite a bit, sorry.'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-07-10 08:19:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I think that "reboot_stop_shutdown_timeout" is too specific - I'd rather go for the values suggested by Sean so it isn't specifically tied to "reboot" and "stop".

Or what about "clean_shutdown_timeout" and "force_shutdown_timeout"?'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-10 18:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Bob - Just to be clear I'm proposing a two step process here:

1) Make it possible to configure a shutdown timeout for stop and delete, with defaults of 120sec for stop and 0sec for delete.  if the names sound specific that's because that's exactly what there are in this step.   They are values for two  operations (three if you count reboot) - not different types of shutdown.

I don't think "forced_shutdown_timeout" makes sense, as that by definition is a a timeout value of 0.  Clean/Forced or Soft/Hard are timeout values - not the parameters as such.


2) Add Clean/Forced as API options to stop and delete (I like those names much better than soft/hard) actions.   At that point we only need one shutdown_timeout value, which would apply equally to reboot/stop/delete  when called with "soft" or "clean"


Would folks feel happier if in step 1 the two configuration options were:

shutdown_timeout (default 120sec)
shutdown_on-delete (default False)

Then when we have API support we remove the second configuration item ?'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-07-11 07:46:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Those options sound better to me'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-12 17:35:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-07-12 18:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I will continue to review the patch'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-09-02 11:25:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

Hi,
There are a few comments inline. In addition to this:
1. There are a number of cases when addition of the new parameter has sometimes been added at the end of the parameter list with a default value and times when it is added in the middle. Would it not be better to be consistent and always have the new parameter at the end with the default value.
2. At the moment functionality is global per all instances that are running. Have you considered maybe doing this as part of meta data from a glance image. That is, when the instance is deployed we can save the type of shutdown in the DB (as system metadata). Then when the instance is shutdown we can read this value and act accordingly. Is this an option?
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-09-02 14:37:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Hi Gary,

I'll look at your specific comments, but to answer the other points:

1) I'll have a look and see what tidying up is possible to make it more consistent.

2) The plan is to allow (via a separate API change) the user to specify the required behavior per-operation.  I could see a case for making the default behavior image specific as well, but I think that should be a third phase rather than trying to do it all now.   Although the defaults are global they are different for delete (clean_shutdown=False) and stop/rescue (clean_shutdown=True)."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-09-06 18:25:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-06 19:20:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-09-08 13:36:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: (2 inline comments)

Hi,
Some minor nits.

Would it be worthwhile considering having metadata on the image properties in glance which enable the functionality that you have proposed. This would save all of the API changes and it would be specific for certain images not global for the entire system.
What I am suggesting is that when you load an image into glance you provide metadata that indicates the following:
 - shutdown_on_delete
 - shutdown_wait_time
These could be maintained on the instance system metadata and then when the instance is terminated they can be invoked. This will enable a more granular functionality and a very small and isolated patch set.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-09-08 17:09:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

Hi Gary,

I just don't see this as an image property.  Lots of users create instances from the same base image, but some want a clean shutdown and others don't.  Some users even want to have a clean shutdown of an instances in some circumstances, and a fast shutdown of the same instance at other times.

For sure some instances are more fussy about this that others, but for our use cases its a per instance / per operation requirement."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-09-08 17:11:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-09-09 12:13:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

Hi,
Sorry to prolong this, but I have one more question:
Why not just make the change specific for libvirt at this stage (we are very late in the game). The behaviour that you propose is not used by the other virt drivers at the moment.
It will also make the patch set a lot smaller and help speed up the review process.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-09-09 14:57:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

Hi Gary,

Way back when I started this (up to patch set 4) it was just implemented in the libvirt layer, but it turned out that there were similar changes also being proposed for Xen - so it was decided to move it up to the virt layer.

Then, since we were aiming at also making the API change in Havana the ask was if I could make the change all the way back to the compute API layer (so that only the API extension needed to added). That lead into a whole bunch of issues getting the change to work with cells (being a non-cells guy, it took a while to work out how that all sits together).

So while I take your point I'm reluctant to split this again back to where I started - it would feel like we're just going around in circles ;-)"}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-09-10 15:18:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

the BP needs approval before this can go it.  Also is it possible to split this up into smaller patches?"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-10-21 14:45:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

Hi Joe,

So what's the correct process to getting the BP approved (given that this change grew from consolidation a few other changes that different virt teams were already working on- and has been under review for three and a half months already) ?

It really doesn't fee like something that its worth taking time up at the Summit with

I don't really see any scope for spliting into smaller patches and still keeping it easily reviewable (this isn't a problem that anyone has flagged as an issue in the 20 review cycles that we've been through so far).  A lot of the "spread" of this change comes from the need to make the same changes into the cells code.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-10-23 12:03:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

@Joe - The BP is approved now, and I don't see any scope for splitting this up and stil keeping it easily reviewable - so would you consider dropping your -1 please ?"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-10-24 08:27:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The way I'd suggest splitting this up is to have one patch that is a functional no-op, which merely adds the new parameters to the vrt driver API & all virt driver impls.

Then have a second patch which actually implements the new feature in libvirt.

This would make the libvirt functional change clearly visible."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-10-24 08:29:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

I'd also suggest that the nova/compute functional changes could likely be separated from the internal API interface changes."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-10-29 17:05:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

@Joe @Daniel:  So I can see that this could be split up, but I don't see any significant advantage in doing that now.   The changes would all still need to be reviewed as a set to make sure that it was actually capable of delivering the end to end   capability, any complexity there is in this change is pretty localised (the range of files touched is more an artifact of the rpc architecture and cells),  and there have been a lot of other reviewers already that clearly didn't have any problem in reviewing the patch as it stands.    Splitting this up at this stage just feels like additional work that could be much better focused on some of the other upstream issues."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-10-29 17:23:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

'}, {'account_id': 4468, 'date': '2013-12-02 02:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-12-03 10:22:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Hi,
Would it be possible to have the 'clean_shutdown' as part of the instance metadata. This will enable us to achieve the following:
1. do not require all of the RPC changes that you have made
2. Do not need additional flags for the driver functions
3. Enable the value to be overwritten - for example the different images should have different shutdown times - this can overide the global variable.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-12-03 10:25:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

I think we really do need a distinction at the API level between forceful shutdown and graceful shutdown. We always want to have the ability to do an immediate hard power off of a guest without delay waiting for a graceful shutdown that may never come.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-12-03 10:45:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

The behavior described in the commit message is specific to types of images that are run. Do you think that this is something that a user of a cloud service should be aware of? It is something that is image driven and hence I think it should be a flag on the instance that is driven by a flag on the image. I just find it kind of messy passing all of the flags and it touches a ton of code.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-12-03 14:00:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30: (1 inline comment)

@Gary - I think its an interesting idea, and I can see why you're making the linkage to images.  I think this may have even come up before in the long running history of this change.

However the range of requests we've had from users around this in our cases led me to conclude that the only way we could meet everyone's requirements was to make the user responsible for if and when they wanted to do a shut down to behave on a per instance basis.  

For example we have users of standard base images that want different behaviour and I really don't want to have different base images (or have the users create their own snapshots) just to cover this, as that would have an adverse impact on the image caching etc.   We've also have users that want to make this decision only at the point where they are going to delete the instance.

I realise this change touches a lot of code to pass the option down from the API, but its pretty simple / repetitive changes and I see that as a one-off tax for not getting this right in the first place (is it really a good idea to just yank virtual power for operations like stop ?)

I'd welcome a subsequent change that allows images to provide their own shut down time as an override (providing there is still a system imposed upper limit) - that sounds like a good enhancement, but I don't really want to hold this change up to include that."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-12-03 19:14:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: No score

@Phil - what you have written makes sense. Will there be API support for this?'}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2013-12-03 20:44:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-12-03 23:36:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30:

@Gary - yes to API support, that's comming as a separate patch"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-12-04 07:46:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks for the clarifications.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-12-05 18:22:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

nice work'}, {'account_id': 7629, 'date': '2013-12-06 20:29:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

This seems like on the virt drivers we should  be doing a soft shutdown... whatever that means... is that about right?'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-12-07 23:28:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30:

@shawn - yep, that's pretty much it.   As per the commit message the aim is to make the default behaviour to give the guest a chance to shutdown before we pull the power, apart from delete where the default is to not do a clean shutdown.

Once the subsequent API patch lands then users will be able to control this on a per operation basis."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-12-10 18:45:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved
