revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-02 14:41:19.000000000', 'message': "Stop and delete operations should give guest a chance to shutdown

Currently in libvirt stop and delete operations simply destroy the
underlying VM. Some GuestOS's do not react well to this type of
power failure, and so it would be better if these operations
followed the same approach as soft_reboot and give the guest as
chance to shutdown gracefully.  Even where VM is being deleted,
it may be booted from a volume which will be reused on anothers
server.

The change is implemented via a new common _shutdown method with
separate timer values so that delete and/or stop can be configured
for immediate processing if required.

Fixes bug 1196924

Change-Id: Ie69aa2621cb52d6fefdc19f664247b069d6782ee

Currently in libvirt stop and delete operations simply destroy the

Change-Id: Ie69aa2621cb52d6fefdc19f664247b069d6782ee
"}, {'created': '2013-07-04 09:13:24.000000000', 'message': "Stop and delete operations should give guest a chance to shutdown

Currently in libvirt stop and delete operations simply destroy the
underlying VM. Some GuestOS's do not react well to this type of
power failure, and so it would be better if these operations
followed the same approach as soft_reboot and give the guest as
chance to shutdown gracefully.  Even where VM is being deleted,
it may be booted from a volume which will be reused on anothers
server.

The change is implemented via a new common _shutdown method with
separate timer values so that delete and/or stop can be configured
for immediate processing if required.

By default the wait time for delete is set to 0 to keep
compatibility with current behaviour

Fixes bug 1196924

Change-Id: Ie69aa2621cb52d6fefdc19f664247b069d6782ee
"}, {'created': '2013-07-12 17:35:01.000000000', 'message': "Stop and delete operations should give guest a chance to shutdown

Currently in libvirt stop and delete operations simply destroy the
underlying VM. Some GuestOS's do not react well to this type of
power failure, and so it would be better if these operations
followed the same approach as soft_reboot and give the guest as
chance to shutdown gracefully.  Even where VM is being deleted,
it may be booted from a volume which will be reused on another
server.

The change is implemented via a new common _shutdown method.

The timer configuration value is moved up to virt/driver so
it can be used by other drivers.

A separate config value defines whether to do a shutdown as
part of delete  (default False to keep compatibility with
current behaviour).

A subsequent API change will add clean/forced options to the
stop and delete methods, removing the need for this
second config value.

Fixes bug 1196924

Change-Id: Ie69aa2621cb52d6fefdc19f664247b069d6782ee
"}, {'created': '2013-07-23 18:27:27.000000000', 'message': "Stop and delete operations should give guest a chance to shutdown

Currently in libvirt stop and delete operations simply destroy the
underlying VM. Some GuestOS's do not react well to this type of
power failure, and so it would be better if these operations
followed the same approach as soft_reboot and give the guest as
chance to shutdown gracefully.  Even where VM is being deleted,
it may be booted from a volume which will be reused on another
server.

The change is implemented by adding a clean_shutdown parameter
to delete and stop methods from the compute/api layer downwards
and into the virt drivers.  The implementation in the libvirt
driver is also provided.  Other drivers are modified just to
expect the additional parameter.

The timer configuration value previous used by soft_reboot in
libvirt is moved up to virt/driver so it can be used by other drivers.

A separate config value defines what the default shutdown
behaviour for delete should be (default False to keep compatibility
with current behaviour).

This code enables a subsequent API change to add add clean/forced
options to the stop and delete methods

Fixes bug 1196924

Change-Id: Ie69aa2621cb52d6fefdc19f664247b069d6782ee

"}, {'created': '2013-10-09 20:00:00.000000000', 'message': "Stop, Rescue, and Delete should give guest a chance to shutdown

Currently in libvirt stop, rescue, and delete operations simply
destroy the underlying VM. Some GuestOS's do not react well to this
type of power failure, and so it would be better if these operations
followed the same approach as soft_reboot and give the guest as
chance to shutdown gracefully.  Even where VM is being deleted,
it may be booted from a volume which will be reused on another
server.

The change is implemented by adding a clean_shutdown parameter
to the relevant methods from the compute/api layer downwards
and into the virt drivers.  The implementation in the libvirt
driver is also provided.  Other drivers are modified just to
expect the additional parameter.

The timer configuration value previous used by soft_reboot in
libvirt is moved up to virt/driver so it can be used by other drivers.

A separate config value defines what the default shutdown
behaviour for delete should be (default False to keep compatibility
with current behaviour).

This code is structured to enable a subsequent API change to add
clean/forced options to the stop and delete methods

Also as a minor tidy-up moved the repeated definition of
FakeLoopingCall in test_libvirt be common across tests

Partially-Implements: blueprint user-defined-shutdown
Closes-Bug: #1196924

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ie69aa2621cb52d6fefdc19f664247b069d6782ee

"}, {'created': '2013-11-29 11:21:41.000000000', 'message': "Stop, Rescue, and Delete should give guest a chance to shutdown

Currently in libvirt stop, shelve, rescue, and delete simply
destroy the underlying VM. Some GuestOS's do not react well to this
type of power failure, and so it would be better if these operations
followed the same approach as soft_reboot and give the guest as

The timer logic itself is changed from simple loop counting with one
second sleeps to a more precise approach, since testing showed that
other calls in the loop could introduce a difference of up to +50% on
the expected duration. This can extent the default two minute to
three minutes, which would not be acceptable in some environments
and breaks some of the tempest tests.

A separate config value defines what the default shutdown
behaviour for delete should be (default False to keep compatibility
with current behaviour).

This code is structured to enable a subsequent API change to add

commit_message:
Stop, Rescue, and Delete should give guest a chance to shutdown

Currently in libvirt stop, shelve, rescue, and delete simply
destroy the underlying VM. Some GuestOS's do not react well to this
type of power failure, and so it would be better if these operations
followed the same approach as soft_reboot and give the guest as
chance to shutdown gracefully.  Even where VM is being deleted,
it may be booted from a volume which will be reused on another
server.

The change is implemented by adding a clean_shutdown parameter
to the relevant methods from the compute/api layer downwards
and into the virt drivers.  The implementation in the libvirt
driver is also provided.  Other drivers are modified just to
expect the additional parameter.

The timer configuration value previous used by soft_reboot in
libvirt is moved up to virt/driver so it can be used by other drivers.

The timer logic itself is changed from simple loop counting with one
second sleeps to a more precise approach, since testing showed that
other calls in the loop could introduce a difference of up to +50% on
the expected duration. This can extent the default two minute to
three minutes, which would not be acceptable in some environments
and breaks some of the tempest tests.

A separate config value defines what the default shutdown
behaviour for delete should be (default False to keep compatibility
with current behaviour).

This code is structured to enable a subsequent API change to add
clean/forced options to the stop and delete methods

Also as a minor tidy-up moved the repeated definition of
FakeLoopingCall in test_libvirt be common across tests

Partially-Implements: blueprint user-defined-shutdown
Closes-Bug: #1196924

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ie69aa2621cb52d6fefdc19f664247b069d6782ee

commit_message:
Consolidate rootwrap settings for neutron element

Moves the root_helper settings for the DHCP and OVS agents
into the common neutron.conf file.

This actually removes a deprecation WARNING from the dhcp agent
logs as well:

Deprecated: DEFAULT.root_helper is deprecated! Please move root_helper
configuration to [AGENT] section.

Change-Id: I79251984ab86b34590dc89139f3c7d02d6175714

commit_message:
Add POWER_MANAGER support to devtest.

Adds an optional POWER_MANAGER option to devtest which can be
used to control the power manager used within the seed and undercloud
images. This can be useful when using the devtest scripts w/ real
hardware.

This support already exists in tripleo-ci and once included in the
devtest scripts will make switching to the devtest scripts in
tripleo-ci easier.

Change-Id: I976aa2f89e965dc9024e7967d7e593fb1f874000

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-16 01:28:53.000000000', 'message': "Pin Sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error:

  error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name (got `...doc/source`)

See: http://bugs.python.org/issue19570
and: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/pull-request/193/builddoc-shouldnt-fail-on-unicode-paths/diff

Change-Id: I0487b4eca8f2755b882689289e3cdf429729b1fb
"}]
commit_message:
Pin Sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error:

  error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name (got `...doc/source`)

See: http://bugs.python.org/issue19570
and: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/pull-request/193/builddoc-shouldnt-fail-on-unicode-paths/diff

Change-Id: I0487b4eca8f2755b882689289e3cdf429729b1fb

second opening tag. This surprisingly resulted in everything above the
keystone_authtoken section not being included in the written out file.

Change-Id: Ib758c350e28980d308b78deff45f81c23da43ebe
'}]
commit_message:
Fix closing cinder.keymgr tag

The tag ending the cinder.keymgr namespace in cinder.conf was in error a
second opening tag. This surprisingly resulted in everything above the
keystone_authtoken section not being included in the written out file.

Change-Id: Ib758c350e28980d308b78deff45f81c23da43ebe

commit_message:
Pin Sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error:

  error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name (got `...doc/source`)

See: http://bugs.python.org/issue19570
and: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/pull-request/193/builddoc-shouldnt-fail-on-unicode-paths/diff

Change-Id: I0487b4eca8f2755b882689289e3cdf429729b1fb

commit_message:
Added missing Neutron package install command for Ubuntu

In the Neutron installation documentation for a dedicated controller
node, there's missing entries for installing on a Ubuntu based
system.

Added the change for Debian also.

Change-Id: Ia30381eca87af273904f3608dc92f519a8ed6741
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: 1261155

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-16 09:28:47.000000000', 'message': "Do not extract ISO with 7z and mount it instead

Closes-Bug: #1260673

During ISO extraction 7z replaces ':' symbols with '_' and truncates some long file names
for Ubuntu packages which breaks Ubuntu deployment.
Example of broken files after extraction:
bsdutils_1:2.20.1-1ubuntu3_amd64.deb => bsdutils_1_2.20.1-1ubuntu3_amd64.deb
busybox-initramfs_1:1.18.5-1ubuntu4_amd64.deb => busybox-initramfs_1_1.18.5-1ubuntu4_amd64.deb

commit_message:
Do not extract ISO with 7z and use mount + rsync instead

Closes-Bug: #1260673

During ISO extraction 7z replaces ':' symbols with '_' and truncates some long file names
for Ubuntu packages which breaks Ubuntu deployment.
Example of broken files after extraction:
bsdutils_1:2.20.1-1ubuntu3_amd64.deb => bsdutils_1_2.20.1-1ubuntu3_amd64.deb
busybox-initramfs_1:1.18.5-1ubuntu4_amd64.deb => busybox-initramfs_1_1.18.5-1ubuntu4_amd64.deb

Change-Id: I4badfcda29c74febb756c6a45b0ed1296cf101a7

commit_message:
Improve autoscaling error message

If we can't find the autoscaling group name produce a more
meaningful error message.

Change-Id: Id7ecae67c9ca8eca0c45b365e9a58caee212c2c9
Closes-bug: #1260111

commit_message:
Rid of specific `dict` methods in object model

This patch refactor usages of objects in unit tests and api. It is only
changing the way object attributes are accessed in the api and object
unit tests.

Change-Id: I9b485ca8523fda65d7c14df8a040de9a89938ffd
Partial-Bug: #1256260

commit_message:
Adding neutron support in openstack-compute

Adding neutron support. It is a search and replace of
quantum with neutron in all the files. Also, set 8.0.0
as the version in metadata.rb. The version was not bumped
when stable/grizzly was branched. Also, updated the
dependency cookbook versions in metadata.rb.

Change-Id: Ia53ffcb0a6fbf322784fb6409adc5386b3e7dd40
Implemented: blueprint neutron-support

Moved common methods and vars to the base class

Changed cleanup approach for floating ips and flavors.
Minor fixes of join() calls syntax in test_mixins.

commit_message:
[vbox] Increasing memory/disk size in vbox scripts.

Closes-Bug: #1253097
Closes-Bug: #1260244

When controller is deployed with Ceph,
768Mb of RAM is not enough. So we have
to increase the default amount of memory
required to run demo environment.
Also, as we now give more space on
controllers for root partition, increased
default disk size as well.

Change-Id: I791f26c94c54ce6be48116fc2eaa9e6464da5738

[{'created': '2013-12-11 07:04:28.000000000', 'message': 'Fix stack_get_by_name does not list embedded stack issue

'}, {'created': '2013-12-12 10:19:47.000000000', 'message': "Fix stack_get_by_name does not list embedded stack issue

filtered with owner_id=None, then nested stacks will not be
listed. The fix is to filter stack_get_by_name by stack name only and
add a new API stack_get_by_name_and_owner_id to filter via stack name

commit_message:
Fix stack_get_by_name does not list nested stack issue

The nested stack's owner_id is not None. When querying a result
filtered with owner_id=None, then nested stacks will not be
listed. The fix is to filter stack_get_by_name by stack name only and
add a new API stack_get_by_name_and_owner_id to filter via stack name
and owner id.

Change-Id: I659104f4936b567222108c211f77473ef35638c6
Closes-Bug: #1240892

subject: Enables db2 server disconnects to be handled pessimistically

commit_message:
Enables db2 server disconnects to be handled pessimistically

A checkout listener can be added to sqlalchemy to be able to handle
database disconnect pessimistically and avoid an error in the event of
a DB restart or simply a temp connection issue due to network
glitches. At the moment only mysql is enabled with this feature. This
patch enables db2 as well.

Sync oslo db.sqlalchemy from commit
bb4d7a2534f6087d828e22784dc263522d309592

Partial-Bug: #1231657

Change-Id: Ib89de07f004975528baffdfd19aae689b089a324

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-15 01:06:29.000000000', 'message': 'Make negative snapshot tests faster

test_delete_image_that_is_not_yet_active is the slowest test because we
wait for the instance to be ready, which times out due to a previous
snapshot action. When trying to snapshot an instance, cancel the
operation at the end of the test as part of cleanup.

Change-Id: Ib3821fd288d21e912a8320392425f063b718abbd
'}]
commit_message:
Make negative snapshot tests faster

test_delete_image_that_is_not_yet_active is the slowest test because we
wait for the instance to be ready, which times out due to a previous
snapshot action. When trying to snapshot an instance, cancel the
operation at the end of the test as part of cleanup.

Change-Id: Ib3821fd288d21e912a8320392425f063b718abbd

commit_message:
Suppress the error message in cleanup-env

"default" pool may not exist before cleaning. Suppress the possible
error message:
error: failed to get pool 'default'
error: Storage pool not found: no storage pool with matching name 'default'

Change-Id: I80b4e3732888c7ebadd03b7792a83dd2a6c411d5
Close-Bug: #1261257

Previously several types of name are used for same type operations
in Neutron releated API method names.

* XXXX_modify -> XXXX_update
* <plural>_get -> <singular>_list
* <plural>_list -> <singular>_list

Closes-Bug: #1261283
Change-Id: I95c268822d1a55ea0440b44ea2c7993979ee4c36
'}]
commit_message:
Make Neutron API name consistent

Previously several types of name are used for same type operations
in Neutron releated API method names.

* XXXX_modify -> XXXX_update
* <plural>_get -> <singular>_list
* <plural>_list -> <singular>_list

Closes-Bug: #1261283
Change-Id: I95c268822d1a55ea0440b44ea2c7993979ee4c36

commit_message:
Updates tox.ini to use new features

tox 1.6 allows us to skip the sdist step, which
is slow. This does that.
It also allows us to override the install line.
In this case, it's important as it allows us to
stop getting pre-release software we were not
asking for.

Original patch by Monty Taylor, talked about here:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-September/015495.html

Change-Id: Id751f7d5d40a80d348a5f5936539d9462b40b14b

subject: added tab showing all servers assigned to a hypervisor

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-13 08:54:16.000000000', 'message': "Cherry-pick the following commits from master:

* Remove 'DatatableOptions' from 'Compose Service' form tabs.
  Ibbba6c360ea46e9164cf326adeedd49ee531bd07
  Closes-bug: #1260312
* Fix issues with namings
  I86a2352fd936991552e9e4355a997c3b479f3f8a
* Fix message about images when there is no any
  Ibfc8622a86065ea8ecd5d6d9e5e49ff34567c5d1
* Fix showing Services list based on available images.
  I518f295930400486f9735d8b23c8ec39af1008cd

This fixes affect user interface (and jump up to the eyes), so they
are better included in release-0.4.

Change-Id: Idea24e356fca65039fdf0ca86aafbef9eba2fb0e
"}]
commit_message:
Cherry-pick the following commits from master:

* Remove 'DatatableOptions' from 'Compose Service' form tabs.
  Ibbba6c360ea46e9164cf326adeedd49ee531bd07
  Closes-bug: #1260312
* Fix issues with namings
  I86a2352fd936991552e9e4355a997c3b479f3f8a
* Fix message about images when there is no any
  Ibfc8622a86065ea8ecd5d6d9e5e49ff34567c5d1
* Fix showing Services list based on available images.
  I518f295930400486f9735d8b23c8ec39af1008cd

This fixes affect user interface (and jump up to the eyes), so they
are better included in release-0.4.

Change-Id: Idea24e356fca65039fdf0ca86aafbef9eba2fb0e

suggestions inline"}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-11-17 06:00:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I agree with the thrust of both Armando and Giulio's suggestions, and would unify their comments with the following proposal:

_check_public_network_connectivity should accept a boolean parameter indicating whether the check should succeed and _ping_ip_address should accept that value and compare it to whether a given ping check is successful, e.g.

def _check_public_network_connectivity(should_succeed=True):
  ...
  _ping_ip_address(should_succeed=should_succeed)

def _ping_ip_address(should_succeed=True):
  ...
  def ping():
     ...
     return (proc.returncode == 0) == should_succeed"}, {'account_id': 8576, 'date': '2013-11-17 08:59:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 8576, 'date': '2013-11-17 09:05:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (4 inline comments)

commit_message:
scenario/network_basic_ops: detach floating-ip

test that a floating ip is successfuly disassociated from VM's port and
VM becomes unreachable

helper:
api/network/common.py
    override update() method for DeletableFloatingIp - handels
    neutron-update and updates self with result

manager:
    _disassociate_floating_ip(self, floating_ip) - use
    DeletableFloatingIp.update()
    _check_vm_connectivity(should_connect=True)
        add negative connectivity test option - will check ping
        only

Change-Id: Iab5f89d92bc2c4ebb9baff2dee4cade0a4cb07d6

[{'created': '2013-12-15 23:39:36.000000000', 'message': "Updated: About OpenStack Object Storage Document

One of the TODO entries was to provide a more comprehensive overview
of Object Storage/Swift than was already written. This is a first
attempt at making it better.

This patch also uncomments a line within the 'admin-guide-cloud' book
that doesn't reference the common 'about-object-storage' page like others
do. I've reverted this and tested thoroughly, not sure why this was there.

In addition, I updated a few other pages where they lacked certain
clarity. For example- the 'Getting Started' page provided only a very
basic overview of the components and without going into too much detail
I added further information. There were also a few English syntax changes
throughout some of the other pages.

Change-Id: I1952d9e1882fc962320304759110a2ccbc50de82
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit c5aaf5424cec06f83c2dcf4730f3042ec4ea73a4)
"}]
commit_message:
Updated: About OpenStack Object Storage Document

One of the TODO entries was to provide a more comprehensive overview
of Object Storage/Swift than was already written. This is a first
attempt at making it better.

This patch also uncomments a line within the 'admin-guide-cloud' book
that doesn't reference the common 'about-object-storage' page like others
do. I've reverted this and tested thoroughly, not sure why this was there.

In addition, I updated a few other pages where they lacked certain
clarity. For example- the 'Getting Started' page provided only a very
basic overview of the components and without going into too much detail
I added further information. There were also a few English syntax changes
throughout some of the other pages.

Change-Id: I1952d9e1882fc962320304759110a2ccbc50de82
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit c5aaf5424cec06f83c2dcf4730f3042ec4ea73a4)

commit_message:
Updated Savanna part of the docs for Fuel 4.0

 * Changed all links to docs and artifacts from Savanna 0.2.2 to Savanna 0.3
 * Also added a sentence to make smooth transition between Additional Checks
   and Platform Tests sections

Change-Id: Ic31a8d79de121f57e8ee4c8099670dc4abf0dffa

commit_message:
Handle non-integer values for if-delete-at

If a client passes us a non-integer value for if-delete-at we'll now
properly report a 400 error instead of a 503.

Closes-Bug: 1259300
Change-Id: I8bb0bb9aa158d415d4f491b5802048f0cd4d8ef6

subject: Revert "Store DIB_* only env variables"
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-03 05:25:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-diskimage-builder-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/22/59622/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-pep8/e18439d : SUCCESS in 30s
- gate-diskimage-builder-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/22/59622/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-python26/ca3cd24 : SUCCESS in 38s
- gate-diskimage-builder-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/22/59622/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-python27/3ddf2d1 : SUCCESS in 30s
'}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2013-12-03 08:12:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Dupicated? https://review.openstack.org/#/c/59621/"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-12-03 10:09:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think it's completely inappropriate for stuff like this:

 declare -x GNOME_KEYRING_CONTROL="/run/user/markmc/keyring-UiPefJ"
 declare -x GNOME_KEYRING_PID="1758"
 declare -x GPGKEY="0x65091615C98A3808"
 declare -x GPG_AGENT_INFO="/run/user/markmc/keyring-UiPefJ/gpg:0:1"

to end up in an image. Sure it's not sensitive (that's why I'm happy to paste it here) but it's still not the sort of stuff you'd feel comfortable being put into an image you might share with others. It will certainly come as a surprise to people, and it came as a surprise to me.

Reproducible builds is, of course, important and capturing any env variable which has an influence over the build would be great ... but capturing all'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2013-12-03 12:37:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It's not clear what things in the environment this saves that would even be needed for reproducability.  I don't think saying "they're might be some things, but we don't know what they are" is not sufficient reason to save everything.

And, if we do know what those variables are, let's document them and tell people how they might affect the build, instead of taking the approach to save the entire environment.

It may not be up to us police people from storing sensitive things in environment variables, yet that's exactly how we tell people to use OpenStack.  From undercloudrc:

export OS_PASSWORD=$UNDERCLOUD_ADMIN_PASSWORD

So, during a devtest run, everyone's admin passwords are getting saved in the images in this file under /etc.'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-04 01:17:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So, the OS_PASSWORD is because that's how openstack clients work, and it's a bug and we should fix it :).

That said, I do take the point about too much garbage being captured; I'm happy for us to capture less, but only capturing the known things is too narrow: I want to revert this change - if I had noticed it I would have -2'd - and we can do a narrower change to blacklist things we consider noise."}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2013-12-04 01:58:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Maintaining a blacklist of environment variables not to save seems quite cumbersome.  Any application out there could set any number of environment variables all of a sudden cluttering up this file again.

Seems much more sane to me to just save environment variables that we know actually affect the build.

Plus I think that saving the entire environment is not what a typical user would expect. Besides passwords, the user may have other sensitive data they don't want saved, such as filesystem paths that contain user account names, installed applications, etc.  That stuff should not be in built images imo."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-12-04 17:43:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Current behavior seems reasonable and sensible, even at the cost of reproducability. Agree it is a bit narrow but I'm not sure we can easily expand that without burdening ourselves with black/white list maintenance.

Perhaps we need to enforce more conventions around our use of ENV vars within the project as a whole."}, {'account_id': 6449, 'date': '2013-12-04 18:06:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So, this sort of thing is why I introduced DIB_* env vars in the first place, so we could clean the build environment *at the start* and know that we're only allowing through things that are deliberately intended to be there.
Unfortunately the environment scrubbing bit never got made, but I would suggest that that be the next piece of this journey. Then maybe some mechanism for folk to whitelist other env vars they care about getting through."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-05 02:37:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've punted this to the list for wider discussion, with a suggested approach to reconcile all the different concerns folk have here so far - I hope."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-08 20:15:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

We have consensus on the list; I'll rework this to store things externally shortly - the other improvements - json/yaml etc can wait."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-16 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-12-16 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-03 05:25:06.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Store DIB_* only env variables"

This reverts commit 7c2d1b2295fb2f6f92896795e36f8f49e6f7d55a

We want to capture aggressively to aid reproducability and diagnosing
issues. Environment variables are not suitable storage for
credentials, it's not up to us to police that.

Change-Id: Id8c5ec589e90bfcc361590bb3ffc76a78767ae02
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Store DIB_* only env variables"

This reverts commit 7c2d1b2295fb2f6f92896795e36f8f49e6f7d55a

We want to capture aggressively to aid reproducability and diagnosing
issues. Environment variables are not suitable storage for
credentials, it's not up to us to police that.

Change-Id: Id8c5ec589e90bfcc361590bb3ffc76a78767ae02

commit_message:
Set up default values for list and map types

Maps and Lists should not return None, they should return {} and [],
respectively.

Change-Id: If61280de22d78f7b335bb326ef02ccd29927bf21
Closes-Bug: #1255903

in properties_schema.

LBaaS for Stingray Traffic Managers

This implements a rest client to configure Stingray Traffic Managers

Implements: blueprint neutron-lbaas-stm-device-driver
Change-Id: I85ccf8f318d2f6488f9fc757a90b517b800ced64
Signed-off-by: Stephen Gran <stephen.gran@guardian.co.uk>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-03 07:06:39.000000000', 'message': "Port deprecate decorator from keystone

This should go into OSLO as soon as possible.

There are a few small changes required for keystoneclient.
- There is no gettext interpreting on the client side.
- We don't have OSLO logging, so log directly to warn.
- Add the missing 'HAVANA' deprecation target.
- A few small test fixes

Change-Id: I187c1f499ad6079b2929deae38a005273e33bfc4
"}]
commit_message:
Port deprecate decorator from keystone

This should go into OSLO as soon as possible.

There are a few small changes required for keystoneclient.
- There is no gettext interpreting on the client side.
- We don't have OSLO logging, so log directly to warn.
- Add the missing 'HAVANA' deprecation target.
- A few small test fixes

Change-Id: I187c1f499ad6079b2929deae38a005273e33bfc4

commit_message:
Use heat function Fn::Replace for clarity

This is much more maintainable than Fn::Join

This change results in identical files on SmokeServer.

Change-Id: Ie19139b833267567a2b2412298d44723afd104fe

so I actually think the function is right, but I'd rather do this the way we are approaching nova extensions. Which is a single variable for enabled_middleware.

If not specified, we assume default of all (which is special keyword). If specified, it's a list of strings for each of the middleware that is enabled."}, {'account_id': 8859, 'date': '2013-12-09 05:23:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Change-Id: I16c83c12feee588afc58b95e54bf2743c5136021
"}, {'created': '2013-12-04 16:14:22.000000000', 'message': "Makes the Swift middleware tests optional

commit_message:
Makes the Swift middleware tests optional

On a given Swift cluster, there's no guarantee that any middleware
will be enabled. Instead of failing this tests should be skipped.
This patch adds an entry to the tempest.conf file for each middlware
describing whether it's enabled or not.

Change-Id: I16c83c12feee588afc58b95e54bf2743c5136021

commit_message:
Remove unused exceptions

Removed the exception classes in the following because not referenced
anywhere.

 -MissingArgumentError
 -NotAuthorized

Change-Id: I9f8d8e865447d772a9c09141b96075620c6d1b07
Closes-Bug: #1259818

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-11 07:14:04.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed check method of $USE_GET_PIP

'[[ -n "$USE_GET_PIP" ]]' always TRUE
because $USE_GET_PIP is '0' or '1'.

Change-Id: I73c4c6befe2126882ef21991b2a3fe712b2ac388
Closes-Bug: #1259824
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed check method of $USE_GET_PIP

'[[ -n "$USE_GET_PIP" ]]' always TRUE
because $USE_GET_PIP is '0' or '1'.

Change-Id: I73c4c6befe2126882ef21991b2a3fe712b2ac388
Closes-Bug: #1259824

Because each project uses a slightly different format for logging, and
sometimes different formats within a project, it is hard to match ERROR as
the log level across all log files. There was a failure caused by "ERROR"

commit_message:
Tighten ERROR regexp in log checker

Because each project uses a slightly different format for logging, and
sometimes different formats within a project, it is hard to match ERROR as
the log level across all log files. There was a failure caused by "ERROR"
actually showing up inside a keystone token. This change will prevent that
though it is still possible something else could slip through.

Change-Id: Ic8b036b4ed7481856231b2d073d273b1df783415

commit_message:
Add tests for SolumException

- fix the exception __str__() method.
- make sure all msg_fmt's are in unicode

Change-Id: I95847a708a9158bf1aabd59370c6c28d643e0874

so are all these extensions always loaded on all environments? If not, how are we detecting which are?'}, {'account_id': 8607, 'date': '2013-10-17 02:06:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Not all are loaded in test environment, tests like update extra route can be loaded in all test environment, others like Change Ifeea2744: Test for the neutron api with provider extension, I add configuration attributes to manage on-off of this test.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-10-17 09:33:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Configurations options are fine for the time being.
Neutron returns all enabled extensions by querying the v2.0/extensions URI.

Tempest might use that during test class setUp and raise a skipException is the extension is not supported.
Extensions, once queried, might even be store in a temporary variable.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-10-17 09:42:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

commit_message:
Remove unused dumps validation in JsonParam value

If the passed parameter is not a valid Json object, a ValueError
exception will be raised in JsonParam parse(). So no need this dumps
validation in value().

Change-Id: Ie450d3923a905b7de3dcbece351aec937ebe7a61

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-10 18:47:51.000000000', 'message': 'Allow docker plugin to run w/o deps

The docker plugin tests would not run without the docker lib being
installed even though the client was mocked in the tests. This
patch adds conditional import of the client and registration of
the plugin so that the contrib tests can be run in the gates
without having to hack requirements or add more third party
libs.

Change-Id: Ia114f8ebc0cf0b72af8e6e5d2c3264fb7952d7f9
Partial-Bug: #1251380
'}]
commit_message:
Allow docker plugin to run w/o deps

The docker plugin tests would not run without the docker lib being
installed even though the client was mocked in the tests. This
patch adds conditional import of the client and registration of
the plugin so that the contrib tests can be run in the gates
without having to hack requirements or add more third party
libs.

Change-Id: Ia114f8ebc0cf0b72af8e6e5d2c3264fb7952d7f9
Partial-Bug: #1251380

commit_message:
Deprecate mox in favor of mox3

Instead of having to use both mox and mox3, just pick
mox3.

Change-Id: I98fde1a748da97db2a8e6ac99d5354b44edb1c28

commit_message:
Don't enable services in os-svc-install

Now that we call os-svc-enable in the individual elements we
can drop the call here.

With this commit *most* services will no longer autostart on first boot
and will rely on post-configuration scripts in os-refresh-config
to enable services. This should clean up our first boot logs
quite a bit...

Change-Id: Ied3622a5e7fce4c3ac2fbd9a0e513ae877cafc5d

commit_message:
Enable some services after installing daemon's...

Update geard and nova-kvm to call os-svc-enable.

Now that we are decoupling service installation and
enabling we need to call os-svc-enable here at install
time.

Should either of these services begin to make use of
os-refresh-config's post install support we should move
the os-svc-enable calls there instead.

Change-Id: I79ee4b2405f81457497ad2591d1bdacda610a426

subject: Call os-svc-enable in post-configure.d
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-01 20:31:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-noop http://logs.openstack.org/98/59298/1/check/gate-noop/d1d3ded : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-01 21:19:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

I really don't like the idea of this; it means we are doing work on deployed nodes that we can do at build time, which is a basic design goal of Tripleo.

I'm happy to discuss the error stuff more - perhaps on list/IRC/etherpad?"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-12-02 01:50:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

lifeless:

To me the issue here is simple: Services should only be configured to autostart once they have been configured. Given we don't create our production ready config files for OpenStack services until after the first time os-apply-config runs this seemed like a simple happy path solution.

As for design goals please point me to any rules I'm breaking here. To me the most important design goal that TripleO should live by is improving how we deploy OpenStack... and I think this fits very much in that mindset.

I'm happy to hear other ideas about how we might resolve the logging issues we have on first boot too."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-02 02:36:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The design approach of images is that we're moving as much complex code as we can off of the node and into the image compilation step. This is something that fits that description: we know exactly what will be in the files, their content won't change, which ones exist won't change.

Whats the issue you're solving - that there are errors in the logs during initial bring-up of a node?"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-12-02 02:56:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

lifeless: I don't think the code I'm changing in the patchset is complex in nature. Enabling/disabling services is pretty straightforward stuff so I would argue that doing the enabling of services (simply running systemctl enable <service_name>) is anything we should worry about in this regard.

And yes. My primary motivation in this patch series is to clean up our first boot logs... although in general I feel like autostarting services (which don't yet have config files) is a really bad idea.

To nit pick your statement I'm not sure we *can* continue to have our services set to autostart at install time and get by with it. That is... if we really expect people to use this set of TripleO elements in production. My personal tolerance for ERRORs on startup is next to nil."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-02 03:57:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So there are two things in particular that are issues with this approach; one is that we're doing arguably unnecessary changes, *in particular* to part of the file system that will be very hard to redirect reliably to our writeable area. Secondly - and this is a slippery path argument - it makes it look like it's ok to have things installed but not used, and thats not ok, because it's a hazard for sysadmins (it makes it harder to tell whats actually meant to be on a node and what isn't.

Another approach would be to error out in the service unit/upstart jobs if the config files we'll be writing don't exist."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-12-02 12:15:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I really like this and it makes a tonne of sense to me

We say "configuration is dynamic" and this is configuration. I don't see how it makes sense to do it at image compilation time.

You don't want an un-configured service coming up, that's more dangerous than the danger of the "complexity" of doing this at build time.'}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2013-12-02 14:18:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I also think that one should never start an unconfigured service. Imho current state is a bug.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-12-02 14:54:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-02 14:54:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-noop http://logs.openstack.org/98/59298/2/check/gate-noop/c25488b : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-02 14:54:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2013-12-02 21:38:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'd like to see this fixed as well, namely, not starting services that we know will fail because they are unconfigured.

To me, I think it would be ok to have the services enabled during the image build.  *But*, they should not be started until os-collect-config has run successfully the first time.  And that sounds like a service dependency problem, the exact type of thing that systemd/upstart should solve well.

So, perhaps we need to be smarter in our service files to express that dependency. For systemd (not sure about upstart), os-collect-config would need some work because currently it runs as a daemon, so systemd assumes it was successful as soon as it spawns.  Where, what we really need is a way to tell if it has run through successfully at least once.  Maybe we can use systemd's notification system here somehow?  That would allow us to then have the OpenStack services depend on os-collect-config."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-12-02 23:39:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

slagle: good points/ideas. One thing to keep in mind is I would like to also consider using real packages with this set of triple-image-elements. Thinking ahead to how that might work I would like to as much as possible stick to stock service scripts as possible. Enabling/disabling a service script at configuration time would be fine... but actually changing the dependencies of the systemd/upstart scripts becomes a much dirtier business. When packages come into play I could for example imagine us using a os-svc-disable script at image install.d time to make sure what we are doing here plays nicely.

Long story short I still like the KISS approach here. Why create/maintain "smart" init scripts when the existing tools already support what we need here... we just have to use the correctly.

Enabling a service *is* configuration. Lets treat it as such.'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-03 05:38:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Dan thats a good point, but there's really two sorts of configuration I think: there is effectively static configuration, and there is the stuff we're actively managing and expect to vary between nodes.

We don't - ever- expect the service units on a cloud to vary between machines running the same image. That makes it not configuration from the perspective of delivering last-mile configuration.

I like Richards analysis that this is a dependency problem - thats a more generalised view of the thing I pointed out - that config files we reference don't exist yet.

In upstart you can wait on things; I'm not sure if you wait on a file being written, but it seems like something that would make sense in principle - Clint, do you know? I presume systemd could do something similar.

Another thing to remember - and this in no way lessons the concern these errors will cause folk - is that these errors will only occur when a node is first deployed : subsequent boots and updates will find config files already existing.

That leads me to observe that when we rebuild a node with a new (say) nova version it may have done non-graceful changes to the config which would lead to errors until the new config is written down, which makes me warm to the idea of not running [some, perhaps all] services until they are configured by the matching config rules for the image.

But - I'm still very concerned about the approach in this patch.

To me, an acceptable approach has the following aspects:
 - it doesn't involve writing to / in the deployed image (as that would break the readonly / feature)
 - there should be no additional ambiguity caused about whats installed vs configured for a sysadmin

I'm not sure about implementation to meet those constraints right now - but one that does won't have the principled objections that I have to this one."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-12-03 15:09:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

lifeless:

You can certainly argue that one of these is static vs. managed configuration. The main concern here however is variance and we won't have any with this approach. Our existing tools already guarantee that. It really is just implementation details we are arguing about here...

To your points about an acceptable approach:

What "readonly" feature. Let us not pretend we aren't already writing to / in a deployed image here! To me writing out a config file in /etc/nova/nova.conf is no different than making a one line edit to /etc/init/nova.conf or running the systemctl enable command.

Regarding your ambiguity about what is "installed vs configured". We install and deploy GCC in our images! Is it configured? I mean... you could call it that. Do you need it at runtime? No. Should it be in our images? Arguably not! I'm quite certain that some systems administrators would think this is a big deal. And yet we do it today. So there, installed... but not actually used (or configured to run). Very ambiguous indeed!

From my prospective the rules you have laid out that *must* be met have all but been violated by other components in our system. And I feel like the bar being set here is a bit high in this regard.

For me, an acceptable approach has to meet the following:

 * work with both source installs (what we have today) and packages.
 * avoid coupling, (each element should fully control its own services)

I'm all for hearing alternative approaches but I have yet to hear one which will work well with the source installs we do here today *and* eventually with packages. Whatever we come up with has to work with both in my opinion without stepping on each others toes (hint: not overwriting service files from my packages).

To me the approach here is still simple and solves the problem at hand. That sounds like a good solution to me.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-12-03 16:24:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Okay. The "readonly feature" was just explained to me. The init scripts are actually soft links which in the future may be kept on a read only partition. Fine by me.

So, what If we do this. In os-svc-enable instead of commenting out the 'start on' directive like I currently do we echo "manual" to a .override file at install time, and remove that file after the config file is laid in place. I  left a comment about that approach here (the initial patch in this series):

 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/59297/2/elements/os-svc-install/bin/os-svc-enable

This would allow newer versions of Upstart > 1.3 to work with this model without editing the actual upstart script.

For Systemd however we still do things as is in this patch series: namely the service is disabled at install time, and enabled only once the initial config file is laid in place.

---

Or, We could make os-svc-enable just a noop for some init systems (like upstart). Anyone using a distro with that init system can simply deal with the initial ERRORs messages. I think this is a bad idea myself but I mention it as a way to move forwards here.'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-03 20:46:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Oops, I meant James!

Lets get this into an etherpad for design work, then we can deliver on it smoothly.'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-03 20:48:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/tripleo-late-start-services'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-12-04 07:31:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I've put a bunch of details in the etherpad about the readonly-root feature in Red Hat's initscripts

tl;dr - we should be able to have a directory of symlinks on the persistent state partition which represents which additional services are enabled"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-12-05 17:59:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-05 17:59:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Call os-svc-enable in post-configure.d

Updates services which make use of os-refresh-config
post configuration to call os-svc-enable to enable
services to start on boot (after configuration).

Making this call here will allow us to avoid pre-enabling
services during installation and get rid of a bunch of
log ERRORs for various OpenStack services.

Change-Id: I32bf9d91723998d200806fda60b9b44fdfe0eb70

subject: Enable services with os-svc-enable

So, I have a different approach for enabling/disabling upstart jobs that I'll propose. It boils down to:

- Keep state in $OS_UPSTART_STATE (/mnt/state/upstart
- Create a job os-svc-enable.conf in /etc/init

    start on starting
    instance $JOB
    env OS_UPSTART_STATE_DIR=/mnt/state/upstart
    task
    console none
    script
      if [ -e "$OS_UPSTART_STATE_DIR/${job}.disabled" ] ; then
        logger -t os-svc-enable "$JOB is disabled by $OS_UPSTART_STATE_DIR/${job}.disabled" || :
        stop $JOB
      fi
    end script


What this does is never lets the job start if /mnt/state/upstart/$job exists. This means even if the user tries a manual restart of the job, it won't start, which is what we want.

This way os-svc-enable can just create/remove these files for enable/disable.

That will eliminate the problem of having to have /etc/init writable when we want a readonly root. Eventually we should push this functionality back up to upstart.'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-05 02:47:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Spamaps you have the sense disabled though. We need an enable facility, not a disable facility.'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-12-05 16:27:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Indeed, it needs work. We can simply make a reasoned order of operations. The logic I would add is:

    if [ -e $UPSTART_STATE_DIR/$JOB.enabled ] ; then
      exit 0
    elif [ -e $UPSTART_STATE_DIR/$JOB.disabled ] ; then
      exec stop $JOB
    fi

What I intend here is that the default position is enabled. One can expressly enable with $JOB.enabled. If $JOB.disabled is present without $JOB.enabled, then truly disable it.

With that, we can simply have os-svc-install add .disabled files to the default state record we want to start with, and then os-svc-enable is required to make it go.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-12-05 17:59:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-05 18:02:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-01 20:31:23.000000000', 'message': 'Enable services with os-svc-enable

Split out the code which enables services to start on boot into
a new os-svc-enable script. This script is currently called by
os-svc-deamon so that services automatically start on first boot
(as is the case with os-svc-install)

The motivation here is to decouple service installation and enabling
so that we can eventually avoid starting services on first boot
until after they are configured. Auto starting services on boot like
we currently do is causing lots of log ERROR messages, etc.

Change-Id: I66d4660c169f5918e924eab1876134891c3a24a1
'}, {'created': '2013-12-02 14:54:47.000000000', 'message': 'Enable services with os-svc-enable

Split out the code which enables services to start on boot into
a new os-svc-enable script. This script is currently called by
os-svc-deamon so that services automatically start on first boot
(as is the case with os-svc-install)

The motivation here is to decouple service installation and enabling
so that we can eventually avoid starting services on first boot
until after they are configured. Auto starting services on boot like
we currently do is causing lots of log ERROR messages, etc.

Change-Id: I66d4660c169f5918e924eab1876134891c3a24a1
'}, {'created': '2013-12-05 17:59:17.000000000', 'message': 'Enable services with os-svc-enable

Split out the code which enables services to start on boot into
a new os-svc-enable script. This script is currently called by
os-svc-deamon so that services automatically start on first boot
(as is the case with os-svc-install)

The motivation here is to decouple service installation and enabling
so that we can eventually avoid starting services on first boot
until after they are configured. Auto starting services on boot like
we currently do is causing lots of log ERROR messages, etc.

NOTE: os-svc-enable is a noop for upstart in this initial commit.
Due to some concerns about editing upstart init files directly
(and changing state on the *future* read only partition) we
will address it in a later commit in this series.

Change-Id: I66d4660c169f5918e924eab1876134891c3a24a1
'}, {'created': '2013-12-05 18:03:48.000000000', 'message': 'Enable services with os-svc-enable

Split out the code which enables services to start on boot into
a new os-svc-enable script. This script is currently called by
os-svc-deamon so that services automatically start on first boot
(as is the case with os-svc-install)

The motivation here is to decouple service installation and enabling
so that we can eventually avoid starting services on first boot
until after they are configured. Auto starting services on boot like
we currently do is causing lots of log ERROR messages, etc.

NOTE: os-svc-enable is a noop for upstart in this initial commit.
Due to some concerns about editing upstart init files directly
(and changing state on the *future* read only partition) we
will address it in a later commit in this series.

Change-Id: I66d4660c169f5918e924eab1876134891c3a24a1

commit_message:
Enable services with os-svc-enable

Split out the code which enables services to start on boot into
a new os-svc-enable script. This script is currently called by
os-svc-deamon so that services automatically start on first boot
(as is the case with os-svc-install)

The motivation here is to decouple service installation and enabling
so that we can eventually avoid starting services on first boot
until after they are configured. Auto starting services on boot like
we currently do is causing lots of log ERROR messages, etc.

Change-Id: I66d4660c169f5918e924eab1876134891c3a24a1

"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-12-09 07:07:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Nice, thanks Clint

This seems a bizarrely distro specific thing to install and e.g. be calling out in the README

Why would this not be a new element (simple 'upstart') in diskimage-builder required by the ubuntu element?


Also, the way dprince was using os-svc-enable, it could be used at build time or runtime ... if used at build time, then we need to allow for an on-image directory in addition to the runtime persistent directory"}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-12-09 23:11:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (3 inline comments)

Thanks for feedback everyone!

It only seems bizarre if you're working on a systemd box. Systemd seems bizarre to me, though it is nice that they actually considered the automated enable/disable case.

This is, for now, specific to TripleO. We aren't trying to push a general distro service enable/disable abstraction AFAIK, but I'd be o-k if it grows into that.

Agreed that /mnt/upstart is wrong though, and I think /var/lib/upstart would be better, then we can move it to /mnt/state/var/lib/upstart when we have use-ephemeral going."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-12-10 02:09:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

So.... I think I'm suggesting it live in /run/upstart/"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-12-10 07:27:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Clint - yes it is bizarre to have (unused) os-svc-enable-upstart installed on a systemd box. Can we avoid that please?'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-12-10 16:17:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Happy to add an if/then block to avoid offending your systemd Mark. :)

Regarding /run/upstart .. that could work, but now we're diverging from systemd unless we teach systemd to also look in an ephemeral place like /run for enabled/disabled. Or, we just make them similar (/var/lib/upstart for upstart, and a bind mounted /var/lib/systemd for systemd) and just disable in pre-configure, and enable in post-configure."}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-12-11 04:56:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-11 04:56:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Works for me

commit_message:
Add a service enable/disable mechanism for upstart

Upstart doesn't have its own service enable/disable mechanism. We are in
need of a facility to enable/disable services without writing to /etc at
runtime to enable a readonly root for image based updates. This command
will be used by later changes to have a generic service enable/disable
mechanism for all init systems.

Change-Id: I931281988aa746f93de190794f68f4c9e628db19

commit_message:
Utilize stack-lock for multi-engine support

Utilize a distributed stack lock to avoid race conditions when multiple
engines are deployed.

Blueprint multiple-engines

Change-Id: I2278c7922557b6234cd7ff162cea92af83e9fb8b

Changes f1b9ac5a and 9f6ff7e3 were aimed at improving the robustness

commit_message:
Switch to using spawn to properly treat errors during sync_state

Changes f1b9ac5a and 9f6ff7e3 were aimed at improving the robustness
of the sync_state method. However both missed switching from spawn_n
to spawn to properly deal with raised exceptions.

Change-Id: Ieda4a5ecca63de67d8a9757962e7e3383fd9c9ea
Related-bug: #1257514

[{'created': '2013-12-09 12:57:35.000000000', 'message': "Update tox.ini to use new features

tox 1.6 allows us to skip the sdist step, which is slow. This does that.
It also allows us to override the install line. In this case, it's
important as it allows us to stop getting pre-release software we
weren't asking for.

Original patch by Monty Taylor, talked about here:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-September/015495.html

Change-Id: I9fe8a6cff149b3b79d434dc955c77a358c43031d
"}]
commit_message:
Update tox.ini to use new features

tox 1.6 allows us to skip the sdist step, which is slow. This does that.
It also allows us to override the install line. In this case, it's
important as it allows us to stop getting pre-release software we
weren't asking for.

Original patch by Monty Taylor, talked about here:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-September/015495.html

Change-Id: I9fe8a6cff149b3b79d434dc955c77a358c43031d

commit_message:
Add support for network name for os::nova::Server

Property 'network' is added to networks schema of the resource
os::nova::Server. It takes uuid or name. The 'uuid' property is deprecated.

Change-Id: I790bd23301ecfb7b8aa22f6c42b9e6c01cd0b186
Closes-Bug: #1247019

That said. LGTM'}, {'account_id': 8399, 'date': '2013-12-13 14:51:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

It took me a long time before I ever got a good explanation either on why the dict-based approach was preferred. You found it though, it's because in certain languages, the translation may cause the variables to be reordered.

On my last project, we'd just made it a rule to just always use dict-based substitutions for all i18n strings, so I didn't stop to think that in this case, since there's only one variable, it's not actually a problem. Apologies for the -1, that should have been a 0."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-15 23:55:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

commit_message:
Command call should log the stdout and stderr

Our utils.execute method did not log the stdout and stderr message
for command call, for these message, they are required for us to
track command call stdout and std error in details.

Change-Id: Ibfb15c3a004f1c2c091e59f452ebaaceeebd934d
Closes-Bug: #1242544

commit_message:
Updates tox.ini to use new features

Reasons:
 - tox update v1.6

Changes:
 - tox 1.6 allows us to skip the sdist step, which is slow.
 - It also allows us to override the install line. In this case, it's
   important as it allows us to stop getting pre-release software we
   weren't asking for.

Original patch by Monty Taylor, talked about here:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-September/015495.html

Change-Id: Ib51796afbfdffb5a879046ca1b94a55b1f6ef6f1

subject: Neutron expects /etc/neutron/plugin.ini
messages: [{'account_id': 6772, 'date': '2013-12-15 23:44:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\nCreated in error.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-15 23:43:37.000000000', 'message': 'Neutron expects /etc/neutron/plugin.ini

Neutron expects /etc/neutron/plugin.ini to contain the Neutron plugin
configuration, or to be a symlink to it. The guide incorrectly referred
to /etc/neutron/plugins.ini (not the s).

The typo has been corrected and the explicity ln command to create the
link added.

Change-Id: Ib81b8f18c71cfc9604cf41f37b7be5d221716c9b
Closes-Bug: #1260173
backport: havana
'}]
commit_message:
Neutron expects /etc/neutron/plugin.ini

Neutron expects /etc/neutron/plugin.ini to contain the Neutron plugin
configuration, or to be a symlink to it. The guide incorrectly referred
to /etc/neutron/plugins.ini (not the s).

The typo has been corrected and the explicity ln command to create the
link added.

Change-Id: Ib81b8f18c71cfc9604cf41f37b7be5d221716c9b
Closes-Bug: #1260173
backport: havana

Neutron expects /etc/neutron/plugins.ini to be the plugin configuration
file or, more commonly, a symlink to the plugin configuration file.

Change-Id: I172e782ba609f7f2250b5ae56d0fee1fe562165b
Closes-Bug: #1260173
'}]
commit_message:
Add command for creating plugins.ini symlink

Neutron expects /etc/neutron/plugins.ini to be the plugin configuration
file or, more commonly, a symlink to the plugin configuration file.

Change-Id: I172e782ba609f7f2250b5ae56d0fee1fe562165b
Closes-Bug: #1260173

I like it.'}, {'account_id': 7896, 'date': '2013-11-25 22:06:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I'm not sure about the use case, but it seems to me that a template could have more than one instance group, in which case you may want to have a different type mapped to "ScaledResource" for each of the InstanceGroup(s). If that is the case, how would we specify the different "ScaledResource"?'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-11-26 10:09:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Edmund, you're thinking of the wrong template. The OS::Heat::InstanceGroup appears in a template written by the user (although this will be optional when the autoscaling API comes about). It in turn programmatically creates its own template (the nested stack) containing OS::Heat::ScaledResource resources, and specifies the type mapping in the environment of the nested stack. So if you were to have two InstanceGroups, even in the same stack, their respective nested stacks would have independent environments."}, {'account_id': 7896, 'date': '2013-11-27 06:07:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yep, thanks for the explanation!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-12-03 02:05:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

commit_message:
Use ScaledResource as type for InstanceGroup members

Use the placeholder type OS::Heat::ScaledResource as the nominal resource
type for resources in an instance group. Use the environment to select the
actual underlying resource type (current AWS::EC2::Instance).

Change-Id: I52252c596fa48e57d927eb78e9d5b7c8261adb3e

commit_message:
tests: Don't access properties_schema directly

Don't rely on the properties_schema containing a dictionary in a particular
format, convert it to Schema objects and use the API. Needed for the
blueprint property-schema-conversion.

Change-Id: I1a0cd93f62bd662752cb27a294248a14446492a9

[{'created': '2013-12-15 22:41:51.000000000', 'message': 'Set pipefail on all devtest scripts

We are missing failures of any commands which pipe their output to
another command. That is particularly troubling as, for instance, we
were recently missing the fact that the overcloud-control image was
failing to build.

Change-Id: Ied3e9a6821d6c19d7e9e82f90a461b62c7b14ddf
'}]
commit_message:
Set pipefail on all devtest scripts

We are missing failures of any commands which pipe their output to
another command. That is particularly troubling as, for instance, we
were recently missing the fact that the overcloud-control image was
failing to build.

Change-Id: Ied3e9a6821d6c19d7e9e82f90a461b62c7b14ddf

Add the node-validate command that triggers the validation of the 'core'
and 'standardized' driver interfaces of a given node. This will also be

Change-Id: I93811c9bfbfe4f7b8559fc4ce566c8d4e19a54ac

commit_message:
Add node-validate to cli

Add the node-validate command that triggers the validation of the 'core'
and 'standardized' driver interfaces of a given node. This will also be
used by the ironic driver on nova to validate the node driver interfaces
before deploying it.

Change-Id: I93811c9bfbfe4f7b8559fc4ce566c8d4e19a54ac

commit_message:
Fix argument mismatch failure for neutron-check-nvp-config

Use sys.argv directly.

Fix bug #1243888

Change-Id: I9cb6ca841d004baf72dd68e44be673c361c2ed05
(cherry picked from commit e3e4a3fa2dac7a03169d095267ec492653524325)

commit_message:
Nicira: Fix core_plugin path and update default values in README

The following patch fixes the core_plugin path in the README file
which broke during the rename of quantum to neutron here ee3fe4e8.
This patch also updates a few of the default values and removes
the promise of adding support for multiple control clusters.

Issue reported by: Ben Lin <blin@nicira.com>

Change-Id: Ia46d80384efaa220685f98afa591177d00021362
Closes-bug: #1260550

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-15 17:48:21.000000000', 'message': 'Pin sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error:

  error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name (got `...doc/source`)

See: http://bugs.python.org/issue19570
and: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/pull-request/193/builddoc-shouldnt-fail-on-unicode-paths/diff

Change-Id: Ibe26f50eb72a0f8687670e0b7d6f280890ea7099
Co-Authored-By: "James E. Blair" <jeblair@openstack.org>
'}]
commit_message:
Pin sphinx to <1.2

1.2 was just released and has a bug that causes builds to fail with
the error:

  error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name (got `...doc/source`)

See: http://bugs.python.org/issue19570
and: https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/pull-request/193/builddoc-shouldnt-fail-on-unicode-paths/diff

Change-Id: Ibe26f50eb72a0f8687670e0b7d6f280890ea7099
Co-Authored-By: "James E. Blair" <jeblair@openstack.org>

commit_message:
Allow heat tests to use already uploaded test image

If $HEAT_FETCHED_TEST_IMAGE is set then tempest is configured to
use the image named $HEAT_FETCHED_TEST_IMAGE for any orchestration
tests which require an image.

Fallback to checking $HEAT_CREATE_TEST_IMAGE and invoking
diskimage-builder if necessary.

The intent is to use Fedora 20 as the test image for gating
since this image has heat-cfntools already installed.

Change-Id: I177ae091a641ba99fd4c618e30a39c5148ae617f

subject: RBD clone from image requires disk_format raw

'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-12-02 14:55:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't know how universal this is.  For block-based backends, this is probably always a good thing.  What about file though?  Maybe they can easily clone qcow, but not raw?  Eric?"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-12-02 19:32:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Agreed w/ Avishay's concern... this makes sense for some drivers but is too driver-specific to be in the manager as-is.

Though it doesn't currently, the GlusterFS driver (and other file-based drivers) could easily support cloning from a qcow2 image to a qcow2 file w/o conversion to raw as an intermediate step.  (We already have glusterfs_qcow2_volumes as a config option to support qcow2-based volumes.)

Something more along the lines of Josh's suggestion in the LP bug seems more appropriate, or, maybe drivers should return information about what formats are supported."}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2013-12-02 20:37:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Eric, fair enough, I suspected that might be the case. In that case it would be better to allow each driver to decide whether it can or cannot clone non-raw images and, additionally, have the driver be able to know whether the image is in raw format when we try the clone_image() so that we don't end up doing a clone of a non-raw image. I'll see if I can find a simple way to do this."}, {'account_id': 8787, 'date': '2013-12-02 21:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

If you decide to let each backend decide whether to clone or copy/convert an image into a volume, my version of the fix for this problem might be a good start:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/58870'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2013-12-04 12:07:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-12-04 12:20:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-28 00:41:01.000000000', 'message': 'Vol create from image force copy if disk_format not raw

When creating a volume from image we now force a full copy
if the image is not of disk_format raw. This implicitly
does a download and convert to raw on the image prior to
creating the volume.

Change-Id: I3fab61196039dc2cc34edef75d5f00989634a99a
Closes-bug: 1247998
'}, {'created': '2013-11-28 11:16:50.000000000', 'message': 'Vol create from image force copy if disk_format not raw

When creating a volume from image we now force a full copy
if the image is not of disk_format raw. This implicitly
does a download and convert to raw on the image prior to
creating the volume.

Also converted corresponding unit test to use mock (instead
of mox).

Change-Id: I3fab61196039dc2cc34edef75d5f00989634a99a
Closes-bug: 1247998

commit_message:
RBD clone from image requires disk_format raw

When creating an rbd volume from image, each driver is now
provided with the image disk_format. The RBD driver will refuse
to do a clone if the image is not of disk_format 'raw' which will
result in the image being converted to raw prior to creating the
volume.

Also converted corresponding unit test to use mock (instead
of mox).

Change-Id: I3fab61196039dc2cc34edef75d5f00989634a99a
Closes-bug: 1247998

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-13 10:03:27.000000000', 'message': 'Simplify security group search logic

This will also speed up search since encoding is moved out of the
the loop. Also, getting all security groups is done only once.
The code to check if multiple matches are found is dead since
nova does not allow creating multiple security groups with same name
Thus there is no need to write another test to check NoUniqueMatch
exception.

Change-Id: I3091ebf87923ca2e6e97e409dc9c2d95f8854af7
Closes-Bug: #1254945
'}]
commit_message:
Simplify security group search logic

This will also speed up search since encoding is moved out of the
the loop. Also, getting all security groups is done only once.
The code to check if multiple matches are found is dead since
nova does not allow creating multiple security groups with same name
Thus there is no need to write another test to check NoUniqueMatch
exception.

Change-Id: I3091ebf87923ca2e6e97e409dc9c2d95f8854af7
Closes-Bug: #1254945

commit_message:
Add CONFIG_SCHEMA to openstack provider

SCHEMA_TEMPLATE was renamed to CONFIG_SCHEMA and moved to the class
scope.

Also, config validation was deleted from OpenStackProvider constructor
for using specified validation method in the base class.

Change-Id: Ia71d1858bd5a8b313e52188bfec3d95f100f5a8c
Related: blueprint common-config-validation

[{'created': '2013-12-11 23:20:54.000000000', 'message': 'NVP plugin: Do backend router delete out from db transaction

Performing the NVP API operation from withing a DB transaction
increases the risk of a deadlock between sqlalchemy and eventlet.

With this patch, the operation is moved outside of the db transaction
and appropriate mechanism are put in place for:
i) ensuring neutron db consistency in case of NVP failures
ii) avoiding deleteing from backend if neutron logic does not allow it

This patch also synchronizes the routine for removing a router
gateway port from NVP.

Change-Id: I58d156e303e7a56ceb8c62766c192e154b0a3bb4
Closes-Bug: #1258150

commit_message:
NVP plugin: Do backend router delete out from db transaction

Performing the NVP API operation from within a DB transaction
increases the risk of a deadlock between sqlalchemy and eventlet.

With this patch, the operation is moved outside of the db transaction
and appropriate mechanism are put in place for:
i) ensuring neutron db consistency in case of NVP failures
ii) avoiding deleting from backend if neutron logic does not allow it

This patch also synchronizes the routine for removing a router
gateway port from NVP.

Change-Id: I58d156e303e7a56ceb8c62766c192e154b0a3bb4
Closes-Bug: #1258150

commit_message:
Cleanup backend loading

Backend creation was happening at import time. This changes the
code so that backend creation time is controlled by calling a
function.

This also allows sharing the backend creation code between the
server and the tests.

Change-Id: Ib817aa341de510a46faa8ed0bc24ef9268fa944b

subject: GlusterFS: Complete snapshot_delete when info doesn't exist

[{'created': '2013-11-19 22:13:59.000000000', 'message': "GlusterFS: Complete snapshot_delete when info doesn't exist

The snapshot_delete operation will fail if the snapshot info file
doesn't contain a record for the snapshot, or does not exist.
This happens in cases such as when snapshot_create fails to commit
anything to disk.

The driver should allow the manager to delete the snapshot
in this case, as there is no action required for the driver
to delete anything.

Closes-Bug: #1252864

Change-Id: I8686a1be09dbb7984072538bff6c026bb84eeb52
"}, {'created': '2013-11-26 22:26:44.000000000', 'message': "GlusterFS: Complete snapshot_delete when info doesn't exist

doesn't contain a record for the snapshot, or does not exist.
This happens in cases such as when snapshot_create fails to commit
anything to disk.

commit_message:
GlusterFS: Complete snapshot_delete when info doesn't exist

The snapshot_delete operation will fail if the snapshot info file
doesn't contain a record for the snapshot, or does not exist.
This happens in cases such as when snapshot_create fails to commit
anything to disk.

The driver should allow the manager to delete the snapshot
in this case, as there is no action required for the driver
to delete anything.

Closes-Bug: #1252864

Change-Id: I8686a1be09dbb7984072538bff6c026bb84eeb52

commit_message:
Remove test that was no longer used for long

test_too_big_volume() case in test_volume.py was legacy from nova-
volume, it was never actually testing anything.  This change removes
this case for good.

Change-Id: I66e0eb80326f039ddc580dec0409fd4090ba5102

subject: WIP: Add ECU setting for libvirt
messages:
[{'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-11-27 08:26:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Now, this prototype is just to discuss what is necessary for implementing ECU.'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-11-27 08:33:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Wangpan:

Thanks for your previous patchset, I hope the blueprint will be implemented.
This patchset is just a prototype, it is OK to drop this if we will find the better implementation.


Is it enough to set cpu_quota and cpu_period on each nova-compute server?

or we need some more intelligent implementation for setting cpu_quota and cpu_period?'}, {'account_id': 4468, 'date': '2013-11-27 08:48:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Hi Ohmichi,
I think it is better to set the cpu_shares parameter at the same time, cpu_shares will be useful while multi instances try to grab a same pCPU.'}, {'account_id': 4468, 'date': '2013-11-27 08:57:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Another opinion, the eventual values of these qos parameters are better to associate with both their flavors and the pCPU capacity of host the instances will run on, rather than hard-code/make configs relate to the pCPU capacity of host. Because that we really want to get the same performance of all same flavor instances which may run on different hosts/different pCPU capacity. isn't it?"}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-11-27 09:13:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Thank you for your fast review.

> I think it is better to set the cpu_shares parameter at the same time, cpu_shares will be useful while multi instances try to grab a same pCPU.

I agree with you. I will add cpu_shares setting also.'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-11-28 10:06:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Another opinion, the eventual values of these qos parameters are
 > better to associate with both their flavors and the pCPU capacity
 > of host the instances will run on

That is an interesting point.
I want to know how to get each pCPU capacity.
Should we operate some benchmark tools on each server just after the deployment?'}, {'account_id': 4468, 'date': '2013-11-29 12:46:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

yes, benchmark tools like speccpu/specjbb should be used for get the pCPU's capability.
The ecu is an unit of cpu capability, so if the instances have same ecus have different performance manifestation, then the ecu conception is not exact."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-12-06 08:03:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-12-06 08:18:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-12-06 08:19:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-12-07 20:13:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

[{'created': '2013-11-27 08:23:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add ECU setting for libvirt

ECU(Elastic Compute Unit) is for implementing the similar virtual
machine performance on several heterogeneous nova-compute servers.

There is the way to configure cpu_quota and cpu_period with flavor
extra_spec already. However, that way can not implement the similar
virtual machine performance on different performance servers.
We need the different ratio of cpu_quota and cpu_period for each
server performance for adjusting the virtual machine performance,
but the extra_spec of a flavor contains the same ratio of cpu_quota
and cpu_period.

This patch adds some configuration items for adjusting cpu_quota and
cpu_period on each nova-compute server.

Related to blueprint nova-ecu-support

Change-Id: I8835fa03d16792dfbec9a9f36f5171c8ea1e3e53
